hashtags:
A night ago, I walked into a cafe in Karimabad and the moment I entered my eyes were transfixed on the lady sitting behind laptop at the far back. She looked up, and yes that was Alyne! For months I was looking forward to see her, but never knew a spontaneous trip to hunza would end up in meeting my favorite woman and the fiery founder of Girls Gone Global. She got up all ecstatic looking at my bewildered yet excited face as I called out her name in disbelief and gave me a huge hug. She was still working at midnight and asked me to sit down and share my views on women rights in Pakistan. 
We had a discussion on the general stigma surrounding the gender, the lost opportunities and ways to mitigate societal vices such as child marriage. I saw the agony in her eyes as she kept listening and typing. There is not one, but countless reasons why I follow her as a mentor and look up to her and one of them is empathy and selflessness which she has for all living beings wether animals or humans. Its her first time visiting Pakistan and she was already invested in doing all she could to become a voice of the unheard young girls and women in this country. I met a humanist that night and a beautiful soul with a heart of gold. 
This was yet again 'Maktoob'. I wish to see the change her efforts will bring in my lifetime. Can't wait to see her again in Islamabad for an all girls meet up. I'll ask you all to put your differences aside and join her so we can all be part of something so revered that will determine the future of our country in coming years. 
@dearalyne ğŸ’•

-
Life will not always give you answers. That doesn't mean you should be passive and live in a boring and meaningless way without letting anything give you all the happiness & love you need.
You can get the opportunity to find your purpose, create it. Maybe it is growing up & making your own family, getting into university, doing the job of your dreams, being famous or rich, helping people, being the reason why someone's life changed or something else. You are going to figure this out. Who knows? Maybe the purpose of life is trying to find it. And it's not pointless as it may seem, it's worth it. Because in the process you learn so much about yourself & others, you are filled with emotions that make you stronger, you develop relationships, you live to know how much you can reach.
Set further goals even if they are too much and difficult for you. Work to do the impossible. It's something that will lead you to great places. Don't give up, explore yourself & your potential. Don't let bad moments or people who didn't appreciate you change or define your world. Don't fear having ambitions and changing them. 
Go get the life you can have & live it to the fullest!
@emmawatson #emmawatson

Turns out there isnâ€™t a single definition- most languages donâ€™t even have a word for empowerment! We believe empowerment enables women to make their own choices, and have the opportunity to turn those choices into actions. Essentially, to have the ability to turn â€œI canâ€™tâ€ into â€œI canâ€. Ehryn Torrell is a London-based Canadian artist interested in visual culture and the myriad ways it impacts human experience and shapes ideas. In a society that profits from your self-doubt, liking yourself is a rebellious act.
ğŸ’«
Dear body,
I apologize for not loving you always. I apologize for not being appreciative of you always. I am sorry for comparing you to others so often.
Today, I want to say I love you and am grateful.
A body that is healthy beyond number of pounds or inches.
A body that is remarkable for being pregnant 4 times and giving me 2 wonderful babies.
A body that is strong for lifting weights and running half a marathon.
A body that is proficient in helping patients and having hands that continue to heal so many.
ğŸ’«
As Iâ€™m getting older, I am learning that I am good enough. No one is perfect and I am going to love all of my imperfections.
ğŸ’«
Thank you Nadia @themindfulmdmom for starting this thoughtful discussion and inviting me to share my thoughts.

hashtags:
While I grew up I learned certain things. Like, you donâ€™t hit woman. My grandparents were quite modern on that topic. I grew up with stories like: â€˜Your grandpa was only allowed to marry your grandma because he promised to send her to school and learn for a job.â€™ My grandpa was definitely a feminist! 
I felt quite strong! And I was certain that something like rape or domestic violence would never happen to me. 
It sometimes feels quite ironical that it happened to me. I always thought I would be a big fighter who stands up for her rights. And in the end it turned out that I was that afraid woman who was a shadow of herself. But looking back, I see the traps now. And I stepped in every single one of them. And sometimes I still ask myself WHY COULD YOU HAVE BEEN SO STUPID? 
The answer is that I always want to do it right. I want to help people. I was in love. It was a slow process. It was like the frog in the pan of water. If you put the frog in boiling water, he will jump. If you put him in cold water and slowly heat up the water till the boiling point (DONâ€™T try this at home!!!), he will stay and dies. 
So I made excuses! 
I told my family that speaking another language made him feel insecure. Oh, they loved him. All he had to do on family visits was to smile (and eat everything my grandma cooked). I never told them that he never wanted to come, I never told them that he hated them. 
I never told him of when he destroyed my things. He sometimes did throw things and afterwards he told me that it felt great. He once told me that, after smashing my ceramic bowl (I gave him grapes in it, washed etc., ready to eat), that it felt so great. His reasoning: he hated that bowl. I loved that bowl. But I kept quiet 
I thought that what he did to me was not bad enough! 
I wanted help but was afraid that nobody would believe me! I mean, I helped him to maintain the image of a perfect boyfriend. 
He threated to kill himself if I would ever leave him. 
He drove like crazy when he was angry. I was not allowed to drive at those moments. I was so afraid he would cause an accident by crashing into a tree or driving of a bridge.

He hurt me!
likes:
|He hurt me! And I was brave enough to confront him with that. He made excuses. I caused it. I was the reason that he got that angry. If I wouldnâ€™t make him angry, everything would be alright. . . . . . . . . and there was so much moreâ€¦â€¦. And I still thought it was NOT a form of domestic violence. Other woman were hit daily. They had to go to the hospital, I didnâ€™t! My case wasnâ€™t that bad. So I kept going!
Until I realized that I had no friend left. I was isolated from my family (hadnâ€™t seen them for 3 years). I was afraid! I didnâ€™t follow my own advice. 
But I knew, somewhere deep down, that it was sooooooo wrong. And my ex always told me that my greatest weakness was my stubbornness, maybe it is one of my greatest strengths.
.
.
.
.

"There are too many people today who instead of feeling hurt are acting out their hurt; instead of acknowledging pain, they're inflicting pain on others. Rather than risking feeling disappointed, they're choosing to live disappointed.
Â·
Emotional stoicism is not bad-assery. Perfection is about the furthest thing in the world from bad-assery.
Â·
To me the real badass is the person who says, "Our family is really hurting. We could use your support." And the man who tells his son, "It's okay to be sad. We all get sad. We just need to talk about it."
Â·
People who wade into discomfort and vulnerability and tell the truth about their stories are the real badasses." -@brenebrown , "Rising Strong" book

âš ï¸âš ï¸TRIGGER WARNINGâš ï¸âš ï¸ "Does human trafficking happen in Canada? I get asked these questions all the time, and my answer is always the sameâ€¦yes, it happens! I know this because I was once a victim of this heinous crime. I was born in the Caribbean but adopted at the age of three to a Canadian family. Growing up, I had a loving but a chaotic childhood. Both my parents suffered from mental illnesses, which increasingly impacted their ability to raise my sisters and me. My school life offered no relief because I was bullied mercilessly for being different. Being the only black kid in my school, I experienced lots of racist taunts, social rejections and bullying on a regular basis.Â  At 16, I left home and started staying with friends, but eventually dropped out of school and ended up in downtown Toronto, where it didn't take long before I became homeless. Bouncing between youth shelters and transitional homes,Â I met a young woman who became my best friend. I admired her fashion, beauty and glamorous lifestyle. What I didn't know at the time was that she, herself, was a victim of human trafficking and was forced to recruit other vulnerable young women. She introduced me to a man who presented himself as my protector and said everything I wanted to hear, promising to take me out of poverty and despair. Through this manipulation and coercion, I was lured into the sex industry, working in strip clubs across Ontario.Â  In the next few months after that, I lived in a state of constant fear and isolation, and under the powerful psychological control of my trafficker. It was only after witnessing a vicious assault on a woman at the hands of her trafficker that I realized that I had to escape this life. I reached out to my street friends from my days of being homeless for help. One would think that this is where the struggle ended. However, even after escaping that life, I struggled with the psychological and emotional trauma of my abuse for much longer. With no resources available at the time,Â I was forced to live with the shame and guilt of sexual exploitation."
[CONTINUED IN THE CONMENTS]
likes: |[CONTINUED HERE] "At 18, I became pregnant with my daughter, which pushed me to try to rebuild my life. First, I completed my GED and then I went on to earn an Honours & Bachelor of Science degree in Health Services Administration and a Master of Science in Health Informatics. Since then, I have built a successful career in the healthcare industry, working as both an analyst and a researcher. In 2018, I launched the RISE initiative, a grassroots project to support vulnerable youth, many of whom are also survivors of human trafficking. Since the launch of RISE, I have had the opportunity to share my story and advocate for different causes that directly impact vulnerable populations like human trafficking, homelessness and mental health. Most recentlyÂ I was part of a review on human trafficking in Canada for the United Nations Inter Press Service and participated in a closed-door round table to increase economic empowerment and entrepreneurship in collaboration with Prime Minister, Justin Trudeau.Â While it is difficult, I hope that by sharing my story, I can help dismantle the stigma and shame that survivors of sexual violence experience even in 2019." ~ @realrhonelle|What a powerful story. A woman empowered is one with power and control over her own life inside and outside the home.â£
â£
In the eyes of Western culture, a woman unable to hold her own outside of the home due to societal constraints is a foreign concept. Lack of skills and, consequently, lack of employment causes women to be completely dependent on their fathers and husbands with no power to control their own circumstances.â£
â£
Our passion for girls education is based on the fact that education is equal to power. Empowerment leads to the ability to affect change. â£
â£
We aren't invested in changing one life. We're invested in changing thousands of lives through one.

Our Male Champion #MCM of the week is Abiy Ahmed, the Prime Minister of Ethiopia and the recipient of the 2019 Nobel Peace Prize. He was awarded the prize for his efforts to â€œachieve peace and international cooperationâ€ after he forged a peace deal with Eritea which ended a 20 year military stalemate following their 1998 - 2000 border war.â£
â£
At 43, @pmabiyahmed is the youngest head of government in Africa and he achieved this after only 8 years in politics. Since he became prime minister, he has introduced progressive and liberalising reforms to Ethiopia. He freed thousands of opposition activists from jail and allowed exiled dissidents to return home. â£
â£
Mr Abiy is a man that understands the value of women empowerment and inclusion. Outstandingly, under him, several women have been appointed to prominent political positions. He gave half of the governmentâ€™s 20 ministerial posts to women, in contrast to the 4 posts which women held in the much larger cabinet of his predecessor, Hailemariam Dessalegn. While explaining the appointments, he said women were "less corrupt than menâ€ and would help achieve peace. He also appointed the first female president, Sahle-Work Zewde. He received an African excellence award for gender from the African Union for this move.â£ #HeForShe â£
#AbiyAhmed is an Ethiopian Male Champion worthy of our respect and admirationâ£

DISRUPT YOUR FEEDğŸ™…â€â™€ï¸ The Express has just published an article on our research study "Disrupting the Feed". Last week we launched our full social media and mental health campaign.
.
In 2018, The Female Lead and Psychologist Dr Terri Apter,Â Fellow Emerita of Newnham College, CambridgeÂ teamed up to explore whether there was a causal or correlative relationship between teen aspiration, mental health and influence of social media. Much current research into  social media usage has focused on keeping safe online and time-limiting exposure to social channels. This research sought to explore whether teenage girls can be encouraged to use social media to expand, guide or reinforce their interests and aspirations by following more high-achieving women on social media.

#heforshe is a movement launched by @unwomen that invites â€œmen and people of all genders to stand in solidarity with women to create a bold, visible and united force for gender equalityâ€. Last week they also co-hosted the screening of the Indian documentary â€˜Son Riseâ€™ by @vibha_bakshi_filmmaker at Siri Fort auditorium in relation to the National Girl Child Day. The movie gave an insight on some of the gender equality issues India faces as well as some of the men who are fighting for gender equality. It was an important event which spread awareness about a massive global issue and encouraged leaders to take part in the fight. It also showed how men can and need to take part in this struggle and use their privilege to lead the way. We recommend everyone to watch the documentary and to go to the â€˜heforsheâ€™ website and register themselves in the fight for gender equality. The link is found in the bio. Thanks to the New Zealand High Commissioner, Dean of Diplomatic Corps and UN Women for inviting us!

Happy Belated Vijaya Dashami to everyone who celebrates! 
Navratri is a 9 day Hindu Festival marking the fight between Shakti/Kali (female embodiment of power) and a demon named Mahishasura. Around India and even around the world, the goddess is welcomed in peopleâ€™s homes and is celebrated in temples where different pujas (rituals) and done for her every day. The tenth day, Vijaya Dashami (literally â€œvictorious tenth dayâ€) marks her victory, against the evil that couldnâ€™t be stopped by any man (or male god). Although these 10 days are celebrated with full fervor in praise of the female power, somehow the importance of equality and respect to women is overlooked through the rest of the year. Why is that? When we are able to see power and strength in a female goddess, why are regular women treated any differently? 
This is a serious conversation that needs to be had, mainly because the education starts at home. When we start treating our daughters the same as our sons and show our boys what it means to stand shoulder to shoulder to the women in their lives, the limiting mentality can finally change. As first-gen kids, itâ€™s our job to change the narrow thinking by setting our own standards and questioning the harmful traditions that are practiced blindly. 
How would you approach this conversation? Do you think itâ€™s possible to bridge the gap between what our scriptures tell us about equality and what is actually being practiced? Comment down below!

ğŸš´ğŸ¼â€â™‚ï¸â£

.

.

Did you know Maya Angelou became an acclaimed poet and writer after being in over a dozen occupations? Young Maya served as a fry cook, nightclub dancer, cast member of the opera, coordinator for a Christian leadership conference, a journalist and even a civil rights activist with Martin Luther King Jr. She was an actress, writer, director, and producer of plays, movies, and public television programs.Â It was the years of insight and maturity gained from doing a spectrum of jobs that led her to write some of the most transformational poetry and prose of her time. ğŸ‘©ğŸ½â€ğŸ“Every experience is a learning experience. ğŸ‘©ğŸ½â€ğŸ“

â€œSorry, Mom!â€ - Aiden (age 13) -

Want a quick â€œbeyond the workâ€ look into what Iâ€™m doing less than 48 hours before I leave for Africa? âœˆï¸ - âŒAm I packing my suitcase? No. âŒDoing laundry? Guess again. âŒCleaning house? Not quite. -

Iâ€™m letting my middle son do a freakinâ€™ FRONT FLIP over me! ğŸ¤£ -

People often ask if itâ€™s hard to leave my family and travel like we do. Itâ€™s extremely hard. My heart literally hurts thinking about leaving them again for 10 days. This was not what I had planned for my life... But you know what? I wouldnâ€™t trade it for anything. I feel incredibly LUCKY to do what I get to do. I couldnâ€™t have dreamed this up 11 years ago this month when my world fell apart and I became a single mother to my three precious little boys. -

The deepest, darkest parts of our stories can be used to bring HOPE to others...if we only let it...ï¿¼and on the other side of that darkness is a HOPE and a HEALING greater than you can ever imagine. -

I can only go and do what we do BECAUSE of the love and support of my husband and boys. When it all gets to be too much, when I tell them that I want to quit, when I tell them I donâ€™t want to leave them again - they are there lovingly pushing me to keep going. â€œYou have to go, Mom. Itâ€™s what youâ€™re supposed to do.â€ -

Over the last three years weâ€™ve worked with thousands of women and girls around the world. I feel so honored to get to be a small part of helping to empower our sisters across the globe - but I also feel incredibly lucky to come home to the love and support of MY GUYS. â¤ï¸ -

Iâ€™ll finish packing tomorrow - but for tonight I have one son to teach how to sew a button on a shirt for his debate tournament tomorrow, one son to take to a sleepover, one son to watch YouTube videos with, and a husband to curl up and soak in these last few hours at home. -

Canâ€™t wait to bring you along on this next journey! -

Hereâ€™s to HOPE... â¤ï¸ğŸŒğŸ’ªğŸ½
~ Ginger

hashtags:
When a person looks out for others they live life to the fullest. 
Dr. Olawale Sulaiman is living well.
.
.
ğŸ“¸ â€¢ @hernetworkonline A What?... A King!ğŸ‘ğŸ¾ğŸ‘‘ | Dr. Olawale Sulaiman, 41, is a professor of neurosurgery and spinal surgery and chairman for the neurosurgery department and back and spine center at the Ochsner Neuroscience Institute in New Orleans.

He lives in Louisiana, but splits his time between the US and Nigeria, spending up to 12 days each month providing healthcare in the country of his birth -- sometimes for free.

Born in Lagos Island, Lagos, Sulaiman says his motivation comes from growing up in a relatively poor region. "I am one of 10 children born into a polygamous family. My siblings and I shared one room where we often found ourselves sleeping on a mat on the floor," he told @CNN.

Dr. Sulaiman said he negotiated a 25% pay cut with his American employer in exchange for longer holidays to Nigeria to pursue his passion. @RNZGlobal has treated more than 500 patients and provided preventative medicine to up to 5,000 people in the US and Nigeria.

Dr. Sulaiman believes that happiness doesn't come from what you get, rather, it comes from what you give.

In His Words; "There is always room to give; you don't need to be a millionaire to give."
-
Source: @CNN
#HerNetwork | @hnwoty
-

PerchÃ© quest'uomo ha il rossetto?

Il mese scorso uno dei relatori ad una conferenza internazionale di Ã¨ reso conto che non c'erano donne nel panel di esperti (configurando un manel --> panel di soli uomini).
SÃ¬ Ã¨ fatto prestare un rossetto dal pubblico, se l'Ã¨ spiaccicato in faccia e ha iniziato a parlare di politiche industriali come se niente fosse, guadagnandosi l'appellativo di #professorlipstick

Al congresso di @voltveneto io e @sailorprinci abbiamo parlato di paritÃ  di genere nella rappresentanza in politica.

Why is this man wearing lipstick?

Last month one of the speakers at an international conference realized that there were no women on the panel of experts (setting up a manel -> panel of men only). He borrowed a lipstick from the public, squashed it in his face and started talking about industrial policies as if nothing had happened, earning the title of #professorlipstick

At the @voltveneto congress I and @sailorprinci talked about gender equality in representation in politics.

#internationaldayofthegirlchild 
Save and Respect the Girl Child Because She is the Future of the Family, Country and the World.

The theme of the International Day of the Girl Child 2019 is "GirlForce: Unscripted and Unstoppable". Women have led global movements on issues ranging from sexual and reproductive health rights to equal pay. Today, most of the girls are attending school and completing their studies. Now, they are focusing on a career. They are not being forced to marry at a young age. Several movements are organized for adolescent girls and tackling issues related to child marriage, education inequality, gender-based violence, climate change, self-esteem, and girls' rights. Girls are proving that they are Unscripted and Unstoppable.

We celebrate the #girlchild today and forever. A girl child is like a bud, let her bloom and be the flower of the future.

No Girl! No Woman! Thus no life.  #thefutureofafricanwomenisnow

I stand for girlsâ€™ right to literacy in all matters of health and intimacy. Access to sexuality education empowers girls, gives them the life skills needed to foster healthier and safer relationships, based on equality and respect. .
We can also prevent gender inequality and violence through access to relationship and sexuality education. Iâ€™m working every day to make sure this message gets across. .
I think itâ€™s important for the EU to continue championing reproductive freedom and safety across the globe, not only through its policies but also through investments. I want to see money going where itâ€™s needed, where it can make a difference in girlsâ€™ lives. .
What is my vision of an ideal future?
âœ… A world where ALL girls have the chance to lead a life free from coercion, threats and violence.
âœ… A world where men and women are equally protected and have the same chances to thrive.
âœ… A world where all people have access to literacy in all matters of health and intimacy. .
What about you? .
~ Camille #GirlsSpeakOut #GirlsTakeOver #EUGirlsWeek .

One of the biggest challenges facing girls is them not being empowered.
.
Too often, too many girls are facing too many challenges which stop them fulfilling their potential. Whether it is not being able to gain an education, that they are not economically empowered, they do not know their rights or that they face violence or discrimination. .
Statistics show worldwide, for every 10 men in a job, only 6 women are in employment. Approximately 15 million adolescent girls worldwide have experienced forced sex at some point in their life. These statistics should make all of us take action.
.
If we want to empower girls, we have to tackle all of these challenges, not only some of them. .
But we can change things for the better if we work together. What kind of world do I imagine for girls in 2030? I imagine a 2030 where girls are lifted up and empowered. What kind of world do you imagine? .
~ Habiba #GirlsSpeakOut #GirlsTakeOver #EUGirlsWeek .
.
.

Itâ€™s not only girls who need to speak out about girlsâ€™ rights and gender equality! As a male and a feminist youth advocate, I want to remind people that we need to involve everyone in the world to achieve gender equality.
.
Itâ€™s not always easy, but this is important to involve everyone. Achieving gender equality is not just a matter of adding more women but recognising the diversity of all people.
.
We need young roles models, and we need decision makers to open up spaces to speak up to people of different backgrounds as well.
.
Any type of discrimination in one area affects progress in another one. Thatâ€™s why we need to keep on advocating and asking for the gender equal representation, visibility and diversification that we deserve. Because none of us are equal until we are all equal.
.
~ Siebe
.

If somebody asked me why it is important that girls are included in decision making processes, my answer would be simple: it is only when girls are heard, that their challenges are really understood.
.
I believe that having girls sit at the table to discuss issues that affect them will result in finding solutions that really work to tackle the challenges they are facing! .
But the reality is that girls are not included enough. If we look at most of our political decision making, thereâ€™s only a small percentage of girls being represented in such spaces, and thatâ€™s why I donâ€™t really believe that girls are truly represented. .
We need role more models. The global participation rate of women in national-level parliaments is only around 25%. We cannot be what we can not see. Thatâ€™s why we need more women in positions of power, making decisions. Only then will we achieve gender equality.
.
I always say, a decision made without a woman, concerning a woman, is a decision made against the woman! Do you agree? Tell me in the comments ğŸ¤—
.
~ Mercy #GirlsTakeOver
.
.

#minoritiesandmedicine

In 2015, women comprised 46% of trainees across all specialties,
34.4% of gastroenterology GI fellows, and
16.4% of practicing gastroenterologists.

I am one of them.

Being a female gastroenterologist, I feel honored and privileged to be exceling in a male dominated field but it comes with some challengesâ€¦

About 41% of female GI reported in a survey that they consider their hand size to be too small for standard endoscope handles resulting in more risk of musculoskeletal and occupational injuries.

I often get mistaken for a physician assistant, as both of my partners are male.

No, where are you REALLY from? Because being a New Yorker is never a good enough answer.

Donâ€™t you want to stay home when youâ€™re husband is a doctor?! You speak English really well. I thought you were Hispanic. (I got that a lot when my hair was colored blonde in fellowship). Youâ€™re too pretty to be a doctor. Why do you want to look at peopleâ€™s BUTTS all the time?! Are you sure youâ€™re a doctor? Are they giving out MD licenses with driver licenses? (I had a patient ask me that in fellowship). How come you donâ€™t cover your head and allowed to work outside the house?

Thank you Maggie @magnoliaprintzmd for starting this discussion. I agree we need more awareness and action because being a GOOD doctor shouldnâ€™t be based on skin color, identity or religious beliefs. We are in it to serve humanity and I donâ€™t discriminate when you walk in my office.
.
.
.

Why pretending? Why are we trying to look perfect in front of others? Why do we try to hide our failures, our weaknesses, our imperfections?
Â·
We have all been facedown in the ground, defeated. We are all imperfect. We all have a story that involves hurt and healing at some point of our lives (maybe even in the present moment).
Â·
People that look like they are always doing fine, being strong, always positive, being always in the right path... They are just good at pretending.
Â·
Be honest with yourself and with others, be authentic and accept yourself, and accept others knowing that there's always a story behind every mask, behind every scar. Have compassion. You never know who's in the process of hurting, or healing. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The United Nations #InternationalDayOfTheGirl is this Friday, Oct 11.  We all need to stand with girls in our lives, in our communities and around the world.  We must break the cycles of gender inequality now, and for generations to follow.  Who can accelerate the pace of change for #Equality? Men joining in to participate.
Did you know that: 
63 million girls arenâ€™t in secondary school worldwide 
15 million girls under 18 are married each year 
781 million illiterate adults are women, making up 2/3 of illiterate adults 
By age 6, girls already see boys as more intelligent and capable of partaking in â€œreally, really smart activitiesâ€ than they themselves are
(all taken from Sheâ€™s the First and UN Women)

The numbers are astounding, but there is so much we can do just by using our voices. 
Malala Yousafzai says, â€œLet us pick up our books and our pens, they are the most powerful weapons. One child, one teacher, one book and one pen can change the world.â€ #alliesmatter #advocates #genderinequality #HeForShe #Manbassadors #feminist

Today at work we took a stand against gender based violence and watched our male colleagues pledge #heforshe

Sridevi is regarded as the First Female Superstar of Bollywood and one of the finest actresses in Indian cinema's history. Sridevi ranked among the highest-paid actors in the 1980s and 1990s and is considered to be one of the most popular actresses of Indian cinema. hashtags: Using these powerful grids from #internationalwomensday2019 to illustrate that itâ€™s not just the bar where women are trying to be out front and top of mind â€” hospitality and interpersonal roles at large are in danger to toxic old world thinking, generational stereotypes, discrimination, isolation, and unsafe spaces. hashtags:
Legend. Lore.â €
â €
The stories that surround a part of our life heavily influence how we perceive of its meaning. Like these pine cones hanging from the rafters of my family cabin. Iâ€™ve heard from a young age about how they came from the tall sequoias of California. How they would fall down from the heights of these giant trees, landing with an enormous thud on the forest floor. Resting until someone came along to discover and treasure them.â €
â €
That might have been the first story that was told to me about the magical land of California.. and still to this day that state, and these pine cones, carry a weight and magic far deeper than any map or â€œfast factsâ€ list could ever convey.â €
â €
I like to think about the legends I tell myself about each part of my life. The journey to Boston, the epic love, the righteous struggle of entrepreneurship. It helps when things come dangerously close to the depressing mundane.â €
â €
Legend. Lore.â €
â €
What legends play in your life? What experiences of your day-to-day will become part of the â€œloreâ€ you pass down to your children and grandchildren?â €
â €
#busthoughts

The hypocritical world we live in today is attached with a complete baggage of expectations for us to "fit in" the so called 'Society'. The expectations to speak, to act, to behave, to pursue, to dress and moreover to impress. 
The daily roles and material stuff are often categorized with the particular genders. 
A guy wearing pink is often regarded as 'a girl'. A girl is expected to be limited to her household or else she's being too bold and dominating. 
The idea of a guy being all tall and muscular and that of a girl being thin and curvy are the only 'body goals' of today's world.  The daily duties of taking care of household and children are quite unquestionably assigned to women without even them acknowledging to it and men are often burdened with the responsibility of having to support their family financially. 
Such little acts often leave a remarkably horrible footprint on someone's mind and can shun them up for lifetime. Our little actions such as a joke or a comment online or offline can change their lives forever and can have some serious questionable impact on their lives. 
So who has the power to change these prevailing stereotypes in our society? 
Of course Us. 
And if we need such things to stop, it starts right from us, from our homes, streets, schools, colleges, workplace and every other place where we can. 
Point out the negative, speak up for it, spread awareness , stand against it and do your best to help out. Don't just sit back and be the silent observer, reach out, talk and provide your support for those who cannot stand up for themselves. 
Uplift someone, strive to make the world a better place. The change begins with you, with me, with US. 
Ps- Stop being judgemental in the name of Sarcasm. Causing mental trauma is not a joke.

Our next introduction is for Ms Shirley Potter, Consultant Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeon.

Ms Potter is currently working at the Mater Misericordiae Hospital, Dublin. She has a strong research portfolio having published widely, while also supervising masters and PhD students under the Irish Intercalated Clinical and Academic Training program. Ms Potter has also completed a Masters in Medical Education and has a special interest in microsurgery simulation. We are extremely grateful to her for agreeing to participate as one of our mentors on October 19th!

Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf was the first elected female head of state in Africa when she took office as the President of Liberia in January 2006. SheÂ signed a Freedom of Information bill (the first of its kind in West Africa) and made reduction of the national debt a cornerstone of her Presidency. To investigate crimes committed during Liberiaâ€™s civil war, she established a Truth and Reconciliation Commission and became a global icon with her commitment to fighting dictators, corruption and poverty through empowerment of women and girls. President Sirleaf and two other female leaders (Leymah GboweeÂ andÂ Tawakkol Karman), were awarded the 2011 Nobel Peace prize for their nonviolent role in promoting peace, democracy and gender equality... On being a minority woman in medicine

Facts (data)
ğŸšº 50.7% of US medical students are female
ğŸšº 19% of all surgeons are women
ğŸšº 22% of full-time faculty in surgery are women
ğŸšº 1% of all surgery department chairs are women
ğŸšº 6% of the members of the Society of Vascular Surgery are women (2013)

Experience (all things Iâ€™ve heard)
- You are too young to be a surgeon.
- Look at todayâ€™s world, women arenâ€™t staying at home.
- Are your kind allowed to work outside the home?
- I thought Muslim women werenâ€™t allowed to work in a manâ€™s field. Is your husband ok with that?
- You speak English very well for your kind.
- Oh you went into medicine because your parents wanted you to.
- Youâ€™ll never get married or be able to have a family because you went into surgery.
- So where are you actually from?

My narrative
My Muslim identity, my Pakistani identity, my first generation American identity, my identity as a woman, my identity as a physician and a surgeon make up my story. That is my story.

I havenâ€™t seen all of these things in anyone, but Iâ€™ve seen parts and pieces in all of the kind doctors who have trained me.

My lesson
The color of your skin, your gender, your religious beliefs, all the labels you use may be different than mine but Iâ€™ve learned that the things that bind us together are so much greater than our differences. We are literally the same on the inside. It may be easy to forget on the daily but nothing is more evident to me as a surgeon.

Takeaway
If you are a student, resident, fellow, trainee of any sort, or a colleague, see this. The numbers are the numbers. Biases exist, and always will. But we are not the numbers. See the opportunity. Continue to pave your own path and find the people who inspire you.

I am asking for more awareness and action.

What can you do?
âœ… Believe us.
âœ… Call it out when you see it.
âœ… Stand with us.
âœ… If you are a man, be a #heforshe.

Equality between genders is the act of easily reaching the same sources, whatever the gender of the person is , that includes the involvement of women/girls in the economical,political,industrial fields and share in the making of decisions and others.
Equality between genders defined as the equality between male and female,under the topic that we are all humans (born equal) ,because both men and women are free to make their own decisions, create their own destiny,and develop themselves without facing the strict stereotypical thinking. 
Equality means that both personal and biological needs for both men and women should ( and must )be taken in consideration and recognition, and evaluated and understand without discrimination or double standards and favoritism that doesnâ€™t mean that women and men MUST be similar but their rights and responsibilities and opportunities DONâ€™T have to depend merely on their gender type. 
Equality means FAIR treatment between both genders, which include the equality in opportunities, benefits, duites and rights.

Day 7 : Emma Watson
Hey everyone this is Jesse your friendly neighborhood French Artist ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡·
And todayâ€™s Inktober is about Emma Watson. It was just logical after Harry Potter. 
Because she became the first one that I called my Favorite Actress. ğŸ¥°
Iâ€™ve always loved her. She inspires me so much and everyday of my life. 
I love how she fights for what is right. And how she uses her celebrity so that people listen to her. 
I am so proud of what she did so far. With the campaign â€œHe for Sheâ€, in 2014, which calls for men to advocate for gender equality.
July 2014, she was appointed as a UN Women Goodwill ambassador and made her first country visit as a UN Women Goodwill Ambassador to Uruguay where she gave a speech highlighting the need for women's political participation.
In 2016 with â€œOur Shared Shelfâ€ : The goal of the club is to share feminist ideas and encourage discussion on the topic. One book is selected per month and is discussed in the last week of that month.
In July 2019, Watson helped to launch a legal advice line for people who have suffered sexual harassment at work.

This is me. Me and my serious face.
Â·
If you know me, you'll know that I'm normally smiling, dropping bad dad jokes. But not this time. This time, an overwhelming feeling of sadness and anger filled me, after a long hard day.
Â·
When I started working on my shadows, I started noticing other men's shadows, how much hurt there is in everyones heart, how deep are the wounds to be healed between men and women. How unconscious we have been while "living" our lives. How much pain we can cause when not being fully aware of ourselves and the ones that surround us.
Â·
There is a lot of work to do, but we definitely can do something to make it better. I'll do my best to guide more men toward their greatest selves. Towards their most beautiful selves. To find their inner light, so they can light up others too.
Â·
Yes, this is my serious face. One full of determination.
This is my purpose, and I'm not stopping.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

October is well underway! 
This October is the 10th(!!) anniversary of Sheâ€™s the First (@shesthefirst): the one and only cause I run for, and have been running for since my first marathon almost 4 years ago.
TL;DR Iâ€™d love your help supporting educating girls around the world. Link in my profile!

Every year I do something new with my running in an attempt to raise money for the amazing work these women do around the world, helping provide opportunities for young women around the globe to get educations and become educated women, leaders in their communities, and make the world a better place for everyone. I really canâ€™t put into words how much I believe in the cause.

This year Iâ€™ve been running a full marathon every monthâ€”that means 9 marathons so far in 2019, each pictured above. Iâ€™m still out of the country for few more days and my attempts to run on vacation have been stymied, but once Iâ€™m home this week Iâ€™ll be back in action! As I come home Iâ€™ll be picking things up for the fall race season with more posts about training, race costumes, past memories, and of course my efforts at my final 3 marathons of the year. As I continue to #SweatForSTF you can also expect much more posting about Sheâ€™s the First. I would be eternally grateful for each and every one of you to consider making even the smallest donation to Sheâ€™s the First. How often do you reinvent yourself? â As I make another trip around the sun today, Iâ€™m reflecting on what new challenges Iâ€™ll tackle this year, and how they will make me grow.

Itâ€™s never too late to learn or try something new. In my forties, I have picked up:
- Tennis
- Writing
- Flatwater SUP
- Fundraising
- Soccer momming
- Social media as a physician
- And lastly, public speaking
â 
I used to be terrified of speaking in a public setting. I could be engaging and funny with my closest friends, but never with strangers and definitely not in front of a crowd. â 
â 
That changed just in the last few years. I learned how much of a voice I have, as a woman, a mom, a surgeon.  Never in a million years would I have thought that I could actually call myself a speaker, but now I do. â In addition to speaking on my experiences as a mom and a woman in Orthopaedic surgery, I also get to MC a few events this year!

DISRUPT YOUR FEEDğŸ™…â€â™€ï¸ The Mail Online has just published an article on our research study "Disrupting the Feed". This week we will be launching our full social media and mental health campaign.
.
In 2018, The Female Lead and Psychologist Dr Terri Apter,Â Fellow Emerita of Newnham College, CambridgeÂ teamed up to explore whether there was a causal or correlative relationship between teen aspiration, mental health and influence of social media. Much current research into  social media usage has focused on keeping safe online and time-limiting exposure to social channels. Your feelings are important! Your feelings are valid! Your feelings are real and nobody can know how it is if they are not you! Don't let anyone dictate or criticize your feelings, don't let them make you think that you are worthless and fake. Don't get caught in that trap.
A lot of people will try to get you down, minimize your struggle, tell you nothing is wrong because they have been through or seen worse. But there is no such thing. Each person has a different body, a different mind, different living conditions, different problems, different ways to cope with bad thoughts and the list goes on. Nobody is you, nobody knows how you see the world, nobody knows how hard things are for you, nobody thinks and feels what you feel the way you do. Someone may think they have had it worse but that means that your situation would be easier for them to cope with than it is for you. Maybe their problems would be easier for you to deal with. But that's the thing; we don't choose our struggle, nobody chooses to be in pain, especially pain that they cannot endure.
Mental illnesses are different on everyone. And even if it's not a mental illness, it's still pain, it's still sadness, it's still stress, it's still numbness, it's still anger, it's still valid!! If it's bad, it's bad. It can hurt. It can confuse you. And you deserve to be heard! You deserve to recover! It isn't some kind of competition and you don't earn something by spreading hate & making people feel even more insecure. Stop comparing, invalidating, trying to pretend you know it all and thinking that people who don't hurt like you don't hurt at all. Instead, spread positivity, love, be kind, smile, don't trigger and promote how bad life is, understand people!! We're all humans, we can all work on ourselves in order to be better. We should change into better. I love you. ğŸ’—
@emmawatson #emmawatson

Meryl Streep has been nominated for 19 Academy Awards, more than any other actor or actress in history. She has won three times â€“ best supporting actress for Kramer vs Kramer (1979) and best actress for Sophieâ€™s Choice (1982) and again for The Iron Lady (2011). Born in New Jersey and educated at Vassar College, Dartmouth College and Yale, Meryl Streep is widely regarded as the leading actress of her generation, not least for her ability to transform herself into a wide range of diverse characters. She has received 29 Golden Globe nominations, more competitive (non-honorary) nominations than any other actor or actress in the history of the award, and won eight times.â €
â €
In 2010, President Barack Obama awarded her the National Medal of Arts and, in 2014, the Presidential Medal of Freedom. She was a founding member of Mothers and Others, an environmental advocacy group which successfully lobbied Congress for new regulations protecting children from the hazards of pesticide exposure. She has underwritten scholarships at colleges and universities, and funds a screenwriting programme for women over the age of 40 through New York Women in Film. In 2015, she sent every member of Congress a letter and a book, Equal Means Equal, supporting the Equal Rights Amendment, a proposed amendment to the US Constitution designed to mandate equal right for women under the law.â €

#22 Limitless: Origami your Life with Aisha Salman now available on Spotify, soundcloud, iTunes ! (soon on youtube) 
Link in the Bio.

@aisha_abd_salman was a Jordanian girl who loved art, and to play, 
So she came up with the Waragami idea, where she could help other people, specially children, to find a good way to play ! She and @laithabutaleb founded this start-up and nowadays they have their own materials, isn't this inspiring?

We talk about her life journey and how she aims to fulfill her life mission,

We talk about her passions and about Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), 17 global goals set by the United Nations General Assembly that she helps to raise awareness about them in order to live in a eco and peaceful world, I am really proud of her work,

Aisha gives advices to people about getting things done and she shares her dreams,

I invite you to listen this beautiful 19 minutes episode !

I really hope to have you as a guest again ^^ Waragami on instagram and on YouTube: @waragamiworld

Meryl Streep has been nominated for 19 Academy Awards, more than any other actor or actress in history. She has won three times â€“ best supporting actress for Kramer vs Kramer (1979) and best actress for Sophieâ€™s Choice (1982) and again for The Iron Lady (2011). Born in New Jersey and educated at Vassar College, Dartmouth College and Yale, Meryl Streep is widely regarded as the leading actress of her generation, not least for her ability to transform herself into a wide range of diverse characters. She has received 29 Golden Globe nominations, more competitive (non-honorary) nominations than any other actor or actress in the history of the award, and won eight times.â €
â €
In 2010, President Barack Obama awarded her the National Medal of Arts and, in 2014, the Presidential Medal of Freedom. She was a founding member of Mothers and Others, an environmental advocacy group which successfully lobbied Congress for new regulations protecting children from the hazards of pesticide exposure. She has underwritten scholarships at colleges and universities, and funds a screenwriting programme for women over the age of 40 through New York Women in Film. In 2015, she sent every member of Congress a letter and a book, Equal Means Equal, supporting the Equal Rights Amendment, a proposed amendment to the US Constitution designed to mandate equal right for women under the law.â €
â €
See her full interview from The Female Lead: https://buff.ly/2oOlplUâ €

People like  Rana and many more such  extraordinary people I call my friends and inspiration keep me going when I embark on my solo rides  trying my best to bring in awareness amongst the girls and women of the villages I pass through about genital hygiene ,cervical and breast cancer.
Sometimes when I feel I can't go on...I look back at such pictures and their inspiring stories...I confidence strengthens to focus on my cause and to move forward. I tell myself ,if this international skater from my city could SKATE the 6000kms of GQ for 90 days and raise money for 25000 nanhi kalis...and continue to smile through it all....what's my excuse to give up?? And then I go on....with new energy and new Josh to my next destination...
So thank you @ranarolling for being a constant support to me and my journeys and for inspiring not just me but thousands of them through your work and humble nature. 
This pic will always remain special to me.

@michaeladeprince is a Sierra Leonean-American ballet dancer. Born Mabinty Bagura to a Muslim family, she was orphaned at the age of three and sent to an orphanage where the â€˜auntiesâ€™ who cared for the children believed that her skin condition, vitiligo, was a curse and called her the â€˜devilâ€™s childâ€™. In 1999, she and another girl from the orphanage were adopted by a Jewish American couple who had 11 children, nine of them adopted.â €
â €
Inspired by a picture of a ballerina she had seen on a magazine cover in Sierra Leone, Michaela trained as a ballet dancer, winning a scholarship to study at the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis School at the American Ballet Theatre. In 2013, she joined the Dutch National Ballet; in 2015, MGM acquired the film rights to the book she wrote with her mother about her life, Taking Flight: From War Orphan To Star Ballerina.â €
â €

Today I have met an older man. I am always watch out for people. I saw him struggling with is mobility scooter. So I stopped and asked If he needed help and if everything was alright. 
Everything turned out to be alright. The scooter worked, he had a mobile phoneÂ  for emergencies, he had an umbrella and he went for a â€˜walkâ€™ with his dog. 
But he kept me talking. I really donâ€™t mind talking to people. Especially if Iâ€™m in no rush. It turned out that he was incapacitated and lonely. We talked for more than one hour standing in the rain (I was standing, he was sitting on his mobility scooter). And he repeatedly invited me to his home. For a cup of coffee or tea. He showed me photoâ€™s of his home (which actually looked lovely and well cared for) 
But Iâ€™m not a person who goes to other peoples homes without knowing them first. 
It just didnâ€™t felt right! So I declined the offer in a friendly way (EVERY TIME). But he kept going! At a certain point he asked me if I was in a relationship. Maybe I was at fault here, but I told him that I was not in a relationship right now.Â  He kept going so I told him that I was a victim of domestic violence and that I donâ€™t visit people I donâ€™t know and certainly not men!!! And writing it down makes me think. Why did I talk to this man for so long. Why didnâ€™t I tell him â€œNo, Iâ€™m not interestedâ€. I did try to leave a couple of times, but I didnâ€™t want to be impolite. 
And he kept going. And I really do believe that this men really was lonely. It is really nice that somebody offers you to paint your apartment (for free). But it was quite intrusive. He told me that befriending him would be beneficial for me. [Do you hear the same alarm bells ringing, I do?) I was having flashbacks, my muscles tighten, I couldnâ€™t breath, I was sweating â€¦ 
My EX always told me if I do what he wanted, everything would be alright. And it would be very good for me to listen to him, fulfill all his wishes. He told me I was always to stubborn and I didnâ€™t know what was good for me. â€œNO, I appreciate the offer, but is doesnâ€™t feel right! I will not go for a visit!â€ And why on earth I didnâ€™t leave at that moment? ......
likes:
|And why on earth I didnâ€™t leave at that moment? I am far too nice!!!!! In the end he â€˜advisedâ€™ me to not listen to my fears. Because I donâ€™t have to be afraid of him. He is lonely and I am lonely and it wasnâ€™t good for me to be alone. 
To make it clear: I AM NOT ALLONE!! Yes, Iâ€™m alone in my apartment. Yes, Iâ€™m not dating. But I am not lonely! 
I donâ€™t want to be manipulated into doing things I donâ€™t want to do! 
And the only thing I learned today was, that I am for to open and for too nice to people! And that I should have left earlier! 
Writing everything down gives me chills again. 
I know loneliness is cruel. But I have the right to make my own choices! 
And looking back to this conversation only shows that this man overstepped his boundaries. If somebody tells you he or she is not comfortable with something, you should not try them to convince them otherwise.

In between passive and aggressive is assertive. ğŸ›‘stop ğŸ›‘ ğŸ¤¯ğŸ¤¯ğŸ¤¯ .

I guess I basically skipped right over that lesson when I was a kid. .

Oh no. Wait.  We didnâ€™t teach our kids about social-emotional well being back then. .

And what was modeled on tv (the babysitter of the 80â€™s... can I get a ğŸ‘ŠğŸ¼ if you were a latch ğŸ”‘ kid) was full of accepted racism, homophobia and â€œboys will be boysâ€ rape culture. .

Most of my life I was strong and confident with a side of aggressive.  This is not because I think Iâ€™m better than anyone (quite the contrary). .

This is how I survived. .

And, when my fire ğŸ”¥ couldnâ€™t protect me, I would backslide into being completely passive. .

Assertive, is being able to speak my truth, and hold my boundary with a humble and kind heart.

Itâ€™s the response Iâ€™m able to find AFTER, I take a breath and get grounded. .

The old way was an automatic response. .

Assertive is a deliberate response. .

For me, this takes practice. 
It takes unpacking. 
It takes community. 
It takes dialogue. 
It takes acknowledgement. 
It takes learning. .

I hope you will join us online for this conversation. .

Personally, curating this course has delivered so many insights. And triggered some great debates. 
Canâ€™t wait to be in our private online forum to really get in there. .

Ramaphabana is a farmer from Ha-Gumbu, close to Kruger National Park in northern South Africa. She decided to start farming due to poverty within her community and family. â€œThose who depend on my business are my three kids, mother-in-law, my husband and my stepson. In total, we are seven,â€ she says.

Starting with one hectare of land she has now built-up the farm to work across four hectares. â€œAfter getting four hectares of land, I realised that the workload is too much so I decided to employ workers in which six are for harvesting and three for spraying,â€ she explains.

On her farm, Ramaphabana grows â€œa variety of nine products, which are okra, onions, two types of spinach, baby marrow, green beans, green peas, gem squash and cucumber.â€ The photos show her and her team harvesting onions and sorting a crop of fresh, green okra.

Ramaphabana is proud of what she has achieved, â€œI excel in farming and there is nothing that I cannot do when it comes to farmingâ€¦Iâ€™m grateful to AWOME, as itâ€™s made me a success.â€ Ramaphabana is one of over 1,250 women micro-entrepreneurs who we are aiming to support through our AWOME (Accelerating Women-Owned Micro-Enterprises) programme. Weâ€™re working in partnership with @UNWomen and governments to accelerate women-owned micro-enterprises across Botswana, Namibia and South Africa.

credit: @hernetworkonline... A What?... A King!ğŸ‘ğŸ¾ğŸ‘‘ | Dr. Olawale Sulaiman, 41, is a professor of neurosurgery and spinal surgery and chairman for the neurosurgery department and back and spine center at the Ochsner Neuroscience Institute in New Orleans.

He lives in Louisiana, but splits his time between the US and Nigeria, spending up to 12 days each month providing healthcare in the country of his birth -- sometimes for free.

Born in Lagos Island, Lagos, Sulaiman says his motivation comes from growing up in a relatively poor region. "I am one of 10 children born into a polygamous family. My siblings and I shared one room where we often found ourselves sleeping on a mat on the floor," he told @CNN.

Dr. Sulaiman said he negotiated a 25% pay cut with his American employer in exchange for longer holidays to Nigeria to pursue his passion. @RNZGlobal has treated more than 500 patients and provided preventative medicine to up to 5,000 people in the US and Nigeria.

Dr. Sulaiman believes that happiness doesn't come from what you get, rather, it comes from what you give.

In His Words; "There is always room to give; you don't need to be a millionaire to give."
-
Source: @CNN

hashtags:
Edgar Ramirez made a speech at the University of Waterloo in Ontario, Canada. He spoke about how the social norms that define masculinity are destructive for men, women and societies as a whole. By making the philosophical question, "what does it mean to be human?", he said that even though it is our feelings that make us human, the expression of feelings is often discouraged by society, particularly for men and boys. The consequences are a burden for everyone and an impediment to gender equality, stating, "In the journey for equality, women and men are like two strands of DNA wrapped together in an embrace. Our burdens are as intertwined as our common destiny. The constraints that burden me will eventually burden you.  And the same is true in reverse: as long as you are burdened, I am too. By recognizing this inter-dependence, I can work for your well-being and know that I am also working towards my own. I can know that whatever action I take to free you, also frees me. This is not just what makes us human. This is what makes us a human family".
.

hashtags:
Marriage is heavy.
âœ¨
My husband and I dated for 10 years but we were clueless as to what we promised to carry when we married 18 years ago. We were kids with rose colored glasses and nothing in our pockets. And, we believed that it was us against the world.
âœ¨
I was fresh out of medical school and my husband had launched his business. Little by little, we carried the weight of being adults by slowly dividing and conquering our responsibilities: the bills and our chores.Â We bought our first home and wove our lives together.
âœ¨
Nothing weighed more on our marriage than the work of having children. Fortunately, my husband was hands on: feeding the baby and changing diapers in the middle of night so that I could sleep longer. From the start, he cared for them solo on the weekends, did the chores and cooked.
âœ¨
When Iâ€™m off, I made sure to lighten his load whenever I could. And as for any hardships inside or outside of our marriage, we tackled them together. But we kept it real too. To prevent us or our marriage from sinking, we also offloaded weight. Besides communicating, being patient and sacrificing, we knew when to ask for help.
âœ¨
Looking back at our 28 years together, our relationship has never been about my happiness or his. It was always ours. We cultivate our marriage by filling our #marriagebox with: so much love, encouragement, appreciation, gratitude, respect, time for each other and ourselves, and generous forgiveness.
âœ¨
Someday when our kids are grown up and itâ€™s just the two of us again, we could feel that we were a team. We each carried the weight and offloaded when we needed to. More importantly, the more we gave the better we became.
âœ¨
Thank you drsarahkiani for inviting me to join the #marriagebox conversation.
âœ¨
What do you put into your marriage box?

We Stan!
Celebrating #BlackHistoryMonth

@Regrann from @hernetworkonline - A What?... A King!ğŸ‘ğŸ¾ğŸ‘‘ | Dr. Olawale Sulaiman, 41, is a professor of neurosurgery and spinal surgery and chairman for the neurosurgery department and back and spine center at the Ochsner Neuroscience Institute in New Orleans.

He lives in Louisiana, but splits his time between the US and Nigeria, spending up to 12 days each month providing healthcare in the country of his birth -- sometimes for free.

Born in Lagos Island, Lagos, Sulaiman says his motivation comes from growing up in a relatively poor region. "I am one of 10 children born into a polygamous family. My siblings and I shared one room where we often found ourselves sleeping on a mat on the floor," he told @CNN.

Dr. Sulaiman said he negotiated a 25% pay cut with his American employer in exchange for longer holidays to Nigeria to pursue his passion. @RNZGlobal has treated more than 500 patients and provided preventative medicine to up to 5,000 people in the US and Nigeria.

Dr. Sulaiman believes that happiness doesn't come from what you get, rather, it comes from what you give.

In His Words; "There is always room to give; you don't need to be a millionaire to give."
-
Source: @CNN
#HerNetwork | @hnwoty
-

ApproximatelyÂ 8 out of 10 sexual assaultsÂ are committed by someone known to the victim. A friend, a family member or even your partner!

No partner in a relationship has the right to have sex! It is something freely given because of love or any other reason YOU are totally fine with (I really wonâ€™t judge here). If you are AFRAID, it doesnâ€™t FEEL good, you have PAIN, â€¦ SAY NO! If he or she doesnâ€™t stop, Â itâ€™s rape!

Victims often blame themselves for behaving in a way that encouraged the perpetrator. Itâ€™s important to remember that the victim is a never to blame for the actions of a perpetrator.

Perpetrators may use, next to physical force, emotional coercion, psychological force, or manipulation to force a victim into non-consensual sex. Â One of the things my ex did, was to force me to stay awake, until he got what he wanted. Sometimes they can be very creative to achieve their goal.

If you are in this kind of a situation, please seek help. Your doctor, a family member, a counselor at work, call an anonymous help line, the police â€¦ there are so much options.

I also want to encourage MEN to seek help. I am a woman and I want to help woman, but I wonâ€™t look away. There is also (sexual) violence against men, so if you are a man, SPEAK UP! You shouldnâ€™t feel ashamed, or feel a lesser man because of it. Donâ€™t give up!

.

.

ğŸ˜³How many of us heard this as a child? Maybe even said it?

For me, it was in elementary school. A boy in my class would chase me, push me, tease me, and eventually pulled down my underwear in front of everyone while i was on the monkey bars. But each time it happened, and each time it escalated, I was met with the same rationalization by the teachers, â€œJust ignore him! He only acts that way to you because he likes you.â€ or â€œHeâ€™s just being a silly boy.â€ What were the ripple effects of hearing this as a child from a person of authority - a FEMALE teacher - whom I adored and still consider one of my best and favorite teachers?

In the immediate, I never even told my parents*. Even though it FELT BAD in my body, I was told it was ok, normal even. So, for the first time of many, I learned to ignore the message my body was sending and that I made a big deal of things that were not a big deal. (â€œDonâ€™t be so dramaticâ€ - another favorite #micro-aggression Iâ€™ll hear a lot). In the long term, I learned to equate an uneasy feeling in my stomach with love - making it hard to separate those amazing new love butterflies with actual warning signs. 
I learned that boys/men donâ€™t need to listen to our boundaries and thatâ€™s just â€œhow they are.â€ I learned that if I wanted attention from boys (which I did) that it could feel gross but that was a good sign.

And what did that boy learn? What had he been told and modeled to behave like that? Looking back, Iâ€™m not sure my teacher was â€œwrongâ€ - I do think he wanted my attention but why was no one teaching others way to get it and boundaries to respect even if he didnâ€™t?

And what happened to my teacher to think the best advice she could give just to ignore and accept behaviors from men that you donâ€™t like?

These are the tough but important conversations that @manifestingmofo and I will be facilitating in our online class SHE PERSISTED through @offthemat By acknowledging these #microaggressions we can create #microhealing and not only feel and do better for ourselves - but have the vocab and resources to model and teach better behavior to our children. We deserve this, our kids deserve this! ğŸ¤Link in bio to register.

Lebogang is a 28-year-old single mother of two. She worked in a salon in earlier years and has a major passion for fashion and beauty, which motivated her to start her own business, LBeauty Salon.

Lebogang is a lively person and believes in looking good. She loves style, which is why these photos look like a fashion shoot. She loved working with the camera. Her favourite parts of her business are Afro hair treatments and interacting with clients. Sheâ€™s very popular and had five regular clients popping in whilst we were filming. In some of the images you can see her having lengthy conversations with them.

She takes training very seriously and has exceeded all her trainerâ€™s expectations. â€œWith AWOME, I learnt record keeping, costing, how to manage my business and keeping my sleep. AWOME made a huge difference because now my salon is operating well, the marketing is so good and Iâ€™m on social media.â€ She has a great relationship with her trainer Kgotlelelo, (â€˜Gotleâ€™). In the images, they are going through her paperwork, her new products and her own LBeauty Oil, which sheâ€™s developed and manufactured herself. She has big plans for LBeauty. "In five years time I want to have a big factory, employing youth like me, with big machines. Right now, Iâ€™m manufacturing at home,â€ she says.

Lebogang is one of over 1,250 women micro-entrepreneurs who we are aiming to support through our AWOME (Accelerating Women-Owned Micro-Enterprises) programme. Weâ€™re working in partnership with @UNWomen and governments to accelerate women-owned micro-enterprises across Botswana, Namibia and South Africa.

Link in bio to find out more.

Dear Emma Watson,

My first introduction to you was like everyone else's, in the role of Hermione. I'd loved her in the books, but oh it was you who brought her to life. And the reason you were so perfect was because you had a bit of Hermione in you. And I had a bit of Hermione in me. It was meant to be.

And when I grew up, and you did too, when life became more than Harry Potter, I saw how real you were. You graduated, started to do other movies and involved yourself in various movements. Whether it was the falling in love with your captive Belle, or the terrified and mistreated Angela, or the bold and confident Nicki, you were nailing it all, and I was a fan. 
But then the exact moment when I realized how inspiring you were was when I saw you campaigning for women and children rights. You started the HeForShe movement and explained how all genders are suffering in some way or other and all need to break from these social constructs. It's been five years now since that started. Your speech in the UN still gives me goosebumps. Your work is making a change and inspires so many each day, every day to work for a better cause.

You came from a position of privilege, and you were able to look past that. You saw what others rarely see and you did something about it. You continue to do something about it. In my opinion, that is the best anyone can do. 
Hermione would be so proud.

Yours,
A HeForShe
.

Associate writer's post by Nishtha (@_nishthaa__ ).

hashtags: I, alongside what is seemingly one in 5 women, have PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome). My bastard little ovaries are ganging up on me. Itâ€™s somewhat a pain in the arse, given that the advisory lifestyle changes include avoiding wine and potatoes (two of my most stable food groups), but a real relief that I finally have an answer to my questions. Throwback post from 2018! Posted @withrepost â€¢ @patmacrn #Sponsored by @allheartscrubs As Breast Cancer Awareness (BCA) month commences, I canâ€™t help but think about all of the women in my life. One in particular, my aunt Bessie, stands out, because she was BCA warrior for over 20 years. â£
â£
I call her a warrior because she was more than just a survivor, she had breast cancer and thrived. In many ways, BCA has been a staple feminists movement. It gave women a voice and made men listen and care. â£
â£
It made talking about a womanâ€™s body, from a health standpoint, less taboo. BCA paved the way for women to talk about other issues that impacted them, such as mental health, abuse, and other topics. BCA shows that women around the world are stronger than weâ€™ve ever imagined. BCA shows us the warrior inside mothers, sisters, aunts, daughters, and cousins. â£
â£
Typically, in epidemiology, mortality rates are presented, showing how many people die in x time-period from a particular disease process or illness. Rather than highlighting that over 41,000 are expected to die from breast cancer, this year. Letâ€™s highlight the fact that every day, millions around the survive to see another day! Thank you to @allheartscrubs for the #BCA gear from 2018! â£
â£

First I want to tell you: Iâ€™m NOT a therapist. So if you know better, I will change the graphic.

My goal was to visualize the circle. It is well known that depression affects motivation. And without motivation you canâ€™t take steps out of the situation. So the situation keeps the same, you get more frustrated, afraid etc.Â  Eventually you get even more depressed. And the circle starts over and over again.

The solution is to break the circle (I know, itâ€™s fare more easy to write it down than to eventually do it)

You need to be good to yourself. That way you will get more energy. With the extra energy you will be able to do more. You will gain moments of success. That will give you a good feeling and you will be less depressed.

Hopefully your downwards spiral turns into an upwards spiral. But note: sometimes you take two steps forwards and the next day is one step backwards. And that is OKAY! You donâ€™t need to be perfect. Go your own pace. Just keep going. By changing nothing, the situation wonâ€™t change.

You can do it!

I challenge you to do one thingÂ  for yourself this week. It can be as simple as using a face mask, or playing your favorite song 10 times in a row. But it needs to be something you normally donâ€™t do for yourself

In my case I started, to wear my earrings every single day!!! #domesticviolence #domesticviolenceawareness #ptsd

ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§Today is a big day. I start working after a 7 months period of parental leave. When I wrote this I was sitting on a train on the way to the office. I had the feeling that I was leaving my kids behind (similar feeling when I left Franki at the kindergarten for first time). However, it also felt like a big relief, like I was going on vacations. â£â£â£
â£â£â£
I understand that this is part of life but it still makes me sad to think that from now on I will see my children only from 6pm to 9pm and it is a shitty anxious feeling. I guess every parent has gone through this stage.â£â£â£
â£â£â£
I am bit anxious to know how my life will look like in the near future. Typically, everything gets automatically sorted out after taking well-enough decisions. But as a person with a chess mentality I need to plan everything months in advance and I trully have no idea how to do it.â£
â£â£â£
One thing that people probably do not acknowledge is the fact that we, as men, have it easier. And please continue reading, this is not some ideology stuff that I want to force you to believe. It is the fact that while women are still considered as the childrenâ€™s main caretaker, they will not be treated equally in the work market. They might not be hired at their 30s because of the risk for the company of a person taking a maternity leave.â£â£ They might lose their job positions or they will get paid less because they are assumed to be less efficient because they have kids to take care of. And other items in a huge list of fake biases. â£â£â£
â£â£â£
If men would take the same amount of parental leave days than woman, then the companies would not be biased by the maternity factor (provided that the society also supports this idea). This is one clear example on how providing benefits to men can also lead to gender equality.â£â£
â£â£

You are the one that should decide how your life is going to be. You don't have to live up to everyone's expectations, because you can't please them all. 
There's not right or wrong, good or bad, beautiful or ugly, normal or not. These are subjective and what matters is what feels real to you!! You define who you can and will be.
Choose your path not only with wisdom but also enthusiasm, live with regrets or not but remember that you can change. You can change yourself when you want to. It's never late to start over. As long as your actions seem bad to you, you can see your life from another perspective and get a chance to become a better version of yourself. People change.
You can be whoever you want to be, do the job you like, dress the way you want to, do what expresses you. If your choices make you happy, then nothing can take that away from you, it'll always come back or you should go and get it.
There are plenty of difficult parts in life and you shouldn't be careless. However, if you love yourself and acknowledge that you are not who others want you to be, that it is YOUR life and it's not going to last forever, I think that it will be much easier and more beautiful. You are enough just the way you are. â¤

MARITAL RAPE â€¢

Sejak tweet saya dua hari lalu mengenai pemerkosaan dalam rumah tangga (marital rape), banyak reply yang tak beradab dan begitu kasar. Banyak netizen yang mungkin shock dan tak habis pikir dengan reply itu. â€¢

Saya pribadi sudah kenyang dengan serangan personal & cenderung tidak peduli. Yang menyeramkan adalah kenyataan bahwa banyak orang yang tidak memahami definisi perkosaan dan menganggap perkosaan dalam rumah tangga itu tidak ada atau menganggap itu sebagai sesuatu yahg baik-baik saja. â€¢

Padahal, banyak sekali perempuan yang sedang hamil, baru melahirkan, atau sedang haid yang menjadi korban pemaksaan seperti ini. Bahkan ada yang akhirnya meninggal dunia. Mereka abai & cenderung tak mau mendengar kisah para korban. â€¢

Itulah kenapa kita harus mendukung disahkannya RUU Penghapusan Kekerasan Seksual (PKS). Dibanding kaget terhadap serangan personal kepada saya, lebih baik kita kaget terhadap fakta bahwa DPR periode 2014-2019 gagal mengesahkan RUU-PKS untuk melindungi korban kekerasan seksual. â€¢ 
Ini harus menjadi salah satu fokus utama kita. Selamat dilantik Bapak/Ibu anggota DPR RI periode 2019-2024, kami akan kawal!

When women say things like â€œmen are trashâ€ â€œmen are pigsâ€ â€œweâ€™re not safe around men aloneâ€ etc. if you get offended or feel like that doesnâ€™t apply to you because youâ€™re not trash or a rapist, good for you, gold star for being a normal fucking human being.

All youâ€™re doing is saying that your fragile little ego is more important to you than someone elseâ€™s experience. As in what theyâ€™ve gone through. As in theyâ€™re speaking on something that happened to them. 
We live in a society where I personally do not know a single woman that has not been the victim of sexual assault on some level or another. Not. Fucking. One.

Female Leads: Roya Mahboob, the first female tech entrepreneur in Afghanistan, where women rarely work outside the home. Roya is working for womenâ€™s education and empowerment by providing access via social media and the internet.â €
â €
Roya Mahboob was born in 1987 in Iran, where her family was exiled during the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan and the subsequent Taliban takeover which precipitated the destruction of girlsâ€™ schools across the country. Her family finally returned to Afghanistan in 2003, and Roya went on to gain a computer science degree from Herat University. In 2010 she co-founded a software company, Afghan Citadel, which won contracts with private companies, government ministries and NATO.â €
â €
She also co-founded Womenâ€™s Annex Foundation (now Digital Citizen Fund), a non-profit organisation that seeks to increase digital literacy by the establishment of computer labs where women and girls learn to use social media and produce content for which they are paid. In 2013, beset with death threats, Roya was forced to move to America on an expedited visa. She has since formed a new company, EdyEdy, an online learning platform.â €

During the 2010 football World Cup in South Africa, the vuvuzela - a long, colourful plastic trumpet - gained international fame for the way it filled stadiums with a loud, buzzing sound of fan support.
â€¢
Nearly a decade later, the instrument has taken on a new purpose in a country rife with violent crime. It is being used to alert women in Soweto, the country's largest township, that their local patrol group is ready to safely escort them to public transport.
â€¢
"I wake up feeling safe when I hear the vuvuzela outside," said Zanele Thusi, a domestic worker, walking towards the train station at 4.30am for her hour-long journey to the Johannesburg suburb of Bosmont.
â€¢
"We could not walk safely in the streets before these patrollers. We would have our cell phones stolen, we would hear of stabbings and daily incidences of crime," Thusi said.
â€¢
South Africa has been making headlines recently as its citizens have taken to the streets to protest the lack of public safety, especially for women, who are frequently murdered, kidnapped and raped, according to women's rights groups.
â€¢
About 3,000 women in South Africa were murdered in 2018 - or one every three hours - which is more than five times higher than the global average, according to the World Health Organization.
â€¢
The patrollers, who said there are thousands of them working in groups ranging from three to 15 members across Soweto, meet women at their homes to walk them to their train or bus station, blowing their vuvuzelas to announce their arrival.
â€¢
Some carry golf clubs, tasers, batons and whips for added protection.
â€¢
"I wish we lived in a society where women were able to walk freely in the streets," said Khanyile, founder of Johannesburg rights group Rise Up Against Gender-based Violence.
â€¢
"But in the absence of this, (the patrols are) an awesome, meaningful, tangible move by men who are taking responsibility for the scourge of gender-based violence in South Africa," she said in a phone interview.
â€¢
Photo + Reporting: Thomson Reuters Foundation/Kim Harrisberg

And after years of abuse, being yourself is quite a challenge. I did not know who I was anymore.

If you asked me for my favorite color, I respondent to the question by saying his favorite color and not mine.

It is PURPLE!!!! Being able to say it now, has such an impact on me. Being able so say purple, for me this is freedom. Discover who you are is another big part of the journey you have to take on.

To become acquainted with yourself again is not always that easy. But you will learn a lot about yourself.
