This October 4th will be the fourth year that red dresses have hung from the trees in Centennial Park in remembrance of the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, Trans and Two-Spirits. The REDdress Project which is now a nation-wide expression of grief, outrage and loss, was created in 2014 by Jaime Black, a Metis multi-disciplinary artist. As poignant as it is powerful, Blackâ€™s installation art project: red dresses and garments hung in wild and public spaces, has become a national action to evoke the memory and honour the humanity of our stolen sisters. 
The REDdress project is a simple but profound way to honour the humanity and the memory of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, Trans and Two Spirits. 
This year take a moment on October 4th to witness these silent representations of lives lost to violence in the intersection of colonialism, racism, sexism, homophobia, transphobia and classism. People are invited to bring red dresses or garments to hang in Centennial Park between 8am and 9am on Friday October 4th, or to hang a dress in their driveways or work place. The dresses will be up all day. There will be a vigil at 4:30pm in Centennial Park to honour our stolen sisters.

|ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§ Since I was a child my models in the world of cartoons and TV series were quite alternative to the typical princesses. I loved FantaghirÃ², Xena, Mulan and Buffy. All these female figures have in common that they know how to make it on their own, they rebelled against conventions and fought for freedom.
I admired them and I wanted to be like them. So, despite never having fought against vampires or barbarians, I "fought" to defeat certain stereotypes and prejudices, especially concerning gender-based violence. In fact, this subject has always struck me so much. I learnt more about it and its aspects thanks to the internship at the House of Women against violence in Modena, during my studies for my bachelorâ€™s degree in psychology at the University of Parma. Thanks to this experience and the stories of the women who came to the facility, I could understand their struggles in getting out of a relationship with a violent person. Moreover, I have deepened, in my thesis, the aspect, often underestimated, of the consequences that witnessed violence causes on children. Later, during my studies for my masterâ€™s degree in School and Community Psychology, I investigated the aspects concerning the representation of gender violence among young people. Becoming increasingly aware that, we should precisely work on the representations and on the language that we use, to prevent this phenomenon in the new generations. And for this reason, I decided to join the project "Beyond what they sell - beyond what they sell" to give my contribution to change in my small way.|If you want to collaborate with us, doesn't matter where you live, contact us, we look forward to sharing new ideas!

â€œI started farming due to poverty within my community and my family. I also saw that women are being undermined when it comes to farming and they are said to be incompetent,â€ says Ramaphabana Nyaluvhani from Ha-Gumbu, close to the Kruger National Park and Zimbabwe border in northern South Africa. â€œI started at home, behind my hut, until I realised the business was growing.â€ The wind whistles past as Ramaphabana explains that she then decided to get more farmland, to grow â€œa variety of nine products, which are okra, onions, two types of spinach, baby marrow, green beans, green peas, gem squash and cucumber.â€ â€œI got into the AWOME programme when the trainers came to my village and introduced the programme on business growth.â€ She explains how sheâ€™s learnt how to keep records, budget and plan for the future.

Ramaphabanaâ€™s pride is evident as she describes the importance of being a female farmer in a culture where thatâ€™s unusual. â€œIt means a lot because women are limited to certain things and I am an example to other women in South Africa. I excel in farming and there is nothing that I cannot doâ€¦my business empowers women by creating employment and I also donate my products to crÃ¨ches, schools and funerals. Iâ€™m grateful to AWOME, as itâ€™s made me a success.â€ Ramaphabana is one of over 1,250 women micro-entrepreneurs who we are aiming to support through our AWOME (Accelerating Women-Owned Micro-Enterprises) programme. Weâ€™re working in partnership with @UNWomen and governments to accelerate women-owned micro-enterprises across Botswana, Namibia and South Africa.

â€¢ Female Empowerment - Not Just For Girls â€¢

Iâ€™ve really been admiring the work of @raisingstrongdaughters  this week. Her fight for female empowerment and being strong role models to your own daughters to lift them up from day one is an awesome piece of well rounded work and I applaud it loudly!

Not having a daughter it made me think about female empowerment from my own perspective and how important it is to me for my own empowerment and that of my female friends and their daughters to be acknowledged, encouraged and enforced; I thought about the men in our lives and how important their attitude is to achieving female strength and it made me realise that we donâ€™t just have to raise strong daughters,  we have to raise respectful and caring sons, and those sons have to have role models in the strong women AND MEN whom they know. 
I want my son to grow up knowing women are STRONG AS FUCK. I want him to see that his mum works her ass off in her job(s) and at home, that she fights for her family (blood and not) and that she can do whatever she sets her mind to. I want him to see that his Dad agrees, that his Dad also does housework, and childcare and works his ass off at work. That heâ€™s proud of the strong females in his life so that my son can follow in both of our footsteps.

I want my son to enable female empowerment by lifting up the females he relates to, by knowing there is strength in feeling emotion, knowing that real men cry, and care and love. Knowing that he can fight, but so can she.

My gift to #femaleempowerment will be raising good sons. Because we all need to be on the same page.

1ï¸âƒ£Heart disease is the world's number 1 killer.
â€¢
2ï¸âƒ£18 million people die every year of heart disease worldwide.
â€¢
â¡ï¸Today on #worldheartday we are on a mission: we want to ensure HEART HEALTH  EQUITY  for ALL.
â€¢
â¤A woman's heart looks very similar to a man's heart from the outside, but there are differences how women develop and present with heart disease.
â€¢
â¤Heart failure is the most rapidly increasing type of heart disease in the world, and women make up 50% of cases.
â€¢
â¤Women are less likely to receive guideline-directed medical treatment to manage their condition.
â€¢
â¤Women are less likely to be referred for transplantation.
â€¢
â¤Women often receive treatment based on data from studies that predominantly enrolled men, and therefore the treatment may not work that well for them.
â€¢
â¤Coronary heart disease is the single biggest killer of women worldwide.
â€¢
â¤If a woman has a heart attack, she is less likely to survive than a man. If the woman is treated by a female doctor, she is more likely to survive.
â€¢
â¤Pregnancy complications such as preeclampsia or early delivery may be warning signs for future heart disease risk.
â€¢
â¤Women are more likely to suffer broken heart syndrome (SCAD) than men.
â€¢
â¡ï¸Heart disease is preventable and we can reduce the risk factors by changing the way we live our lives. Very few people know about all these points above. Please tag a woman who needs to hear this. â€¢
â¡ï¸This year on #worldheartday we are on a mission to ensure we are creating heart health equity for all. â€¢
â¡ï¸We want to create communities of heart heroines & heroes. #sheforshe #heforshe
â€¢
â¡ï¸We promise to ourselves, our families to eat more healthily. Know our blood pressure. Stop smoking. Move more.
â€¢
â¡ï¸We share our promise and inspire others.
â€¢
â¡ï¸We promise as healthcare professionals that we help patients to give up smoking and to lower their cholesterol. â€¢
â¡ï¸We promise to keep our promise...for
MY Heart, for Your Heart, for All OUR HEARTS, because our hearts matter.

hashtags:
Taking good care of yourself is a very big step! People in extreme circumstances tend to neglect themselves. We hear we are worthless, that we arenâ€™t pretty enough, that we donâ€™t work hard enoughâ€¦ I only tried to make him happyâ€¦ or at least avoid making him angry. There was no time, money or energy left for me!

A some point in life I stood up at 5 AM, before going to work I prepared his breakfast and clothing. (he didnâ€™t work!) At 7 AM I started work. I left office at 15:30PM. I was rushing to the grocery store, do the shopping. When I arrived home around 17:00PM I started to cook, so dinner would be ready at 6! After dinner it started! He talked hours and hours. How the whole world was against him, that I didnâ€™t clean the house, why I was tired, couldnâ€™t I wear a sexy dress with high heel shoes? etc â€¦ I was exhausted going to bed at 1 oâ€™clock in the morning. And after a max of 4 hours sleep I had to get up again. With no ME-TIME at all! (and I donâ€™t talk about the bad days, this is a description of a good day)

Looking back it comes to no surprise I became ill. I wonâ€™t say he made me sick. But by exhausting myself like this, my health resistance probably was at an extreme LOW!

After (of more precise during the brake up period) I left him, I started to change. I tried to be good to myself! Why would be anybody good to me, while I donâ€™t live the example.

My sleep rhythm is still of! But it is far better than the 1 to 2 hours sleep a day I had the last half year (at least) of my relationship. I always tried to maintain Â a good day/night rhythm. I try to sleep at night and be awake while the sun is shining. If Iâ€™m exhausted I take a nap in the afternoon.

I tried to put some work in my looks. It is hard when you are in the middle of a depression. Even changing your cloth is so difficult. Â So I make a list in my head what I had to do EVERY DAY. This list was like: -  Brush your teeth (at least twice a day) -  Take a shower -  Clean your face -  Use skin care products -  Change cloth. Wear nice cloth even if you donâ€™t leave the house -  Use make up (from time to time)
likes:
|- Wear earrings (I love earrings, My ex told me wearing earrings is ugly â€“ Guess what I wear EVERY DAY nowadays!!!)
-  Do your hair 
I started to go to a hairdresser after so many years. I put all my money into him. He went out for a haircut. I colored and cut my hair myself. It felt like becoming a completely different person, in a good way. I became a little bit like ME again. Or the person I should have been the whole time.
And I found a good one! You never leave the shop unstyled. Sometimes they curl my hair and I even got an amazing fishtail braid once! It made me shine again.
While leaving him I made a choice. I didnâ€™t tell our friends. I didnâ€™t want to get involved in a mud fight. I didnâ€™t want to justify why I was leaving. And I definitely didnâ€™t want to meet my ex during birthday parties. I wanted to be free! So I not only became single but I also lost all my friends (which apparently wasnâ€™t a big loss because nobody called me to ask my side of the story. One female â€˜friendâ€™ even walked past me a couple of weeks ago and didnâ€™t stop to say â€˜hi!â€™. She ignored me and looked to the other side) That makes you really lonely. I moved, I didnâ€™t now anybody. It would have been so easy to stay at home and cry all day.
I forced myself to go outside. I explored the area. I went for a walk every day (at least once). It was after my car accident. So I had several braces and a casts to wear, which made it impossible for me to exercise. I got a membership at the cinema. I went there to watch movies. I had to leave the house, walk for 20 minutes to go to the train station, take the train, walk 15 minutes to the cinema to watch the movie. And going home afterwards. I always got so much energy from it.|I talked to people. Even if it was the cashier at the grocery store. I went to the women emancipation center. I talked to people in the waiting room while visiting my doctors. I went to lectures. I visited my family more often (it is a 4 hour train ride â€“ one way!!). I did everything to come out of de isolation.
Currently I looking into my hobbies. In my case, the difficult part is finding something that have no big impact on my hands. My right hand got severely damaged during that accident and I canâ€™t use my right hand as I used to be. I already had one surgery. The results are better than expected. I am actually able to move my wrist. The remainder is work in progress! Why is it important? Because I love working with my hands. I like crafting, knitting, sewing, doing some DIY stuff (I still need to paint my bench white)â€¦ the last couple of weeks Iâ€™m thinking of picking up photography again. During my time at university I took several courses. But I never had the time to do something with it. I never had ME TIME. I also discovered that some photos I took were deleted by my ex. (It must have happened in the last weeks living together.) But Iâ€™m starting over, I always can take new ones.
I wonâ€™t give up!
And I like DANCING!!!
By doing all this, I get a better balance in life. I try to keep my life as structured and organized as possible. And it really helps my mental wellbeing. I look more rested, I smile more, I get compliments that I am shining and look more beautiful and happy. And especially on difficult days I try to all of this above. At some point it will become a routine.Â  Selfcare is crucial!
I wonâ€™t say it will solve all problems, but maybe you will be able to love yourself again. Because I did!

Itâ€™s National Sons Day.  And, the most important thing I can do as a mama of 2 boys is to teach them how to navigate this world with compassion, empathy and respect for all.

I bought this book for Arya.  And, I turned around and the boys were completely engrossed in it and I snapped a quick pic because I thought it was so cute that they were reading side by side.
.
But, I was surprised at first that they liked this book.  And then, I paused, and forced myself to examine why I was surprised they would gravitate towards this book, when I try so hard to teach them exactly this very lesson.  That to be a pioneer is not a male or female trait.  Whereas I focused on the â€œWOMENâ€ in science.  They focused on the PIONEERS in Science, not even noticing that all the stories were of women.

This is it.  The next generation.  Change starts right here. #heforshe #nationalsonsday #brotherlove

Have you ever been treated unfairly because of someone elseâ€™s unconscious or implicit bias?  So many of us have been, and it can be really difficult to know how to react.  Many years ago, when I joined the board of The Duke of Edinburghâ€™s Award and attended a drinks reception at Buckingham Palace, I put out my hand to introduce myself to my new fellow board member (a white man of a certain age!) and he put his empty coffee cup in my hand and walked away.  He presumed I was the waiting staff. I just took the cup, with my mouth hanging open in total shock. I didnâ€™t know what to say. I didnâ€™t want to come across as some overly sensitive young woman and I didnâ€™t want to make a scene.  So, I said nothing.  I really regret that now as my silence sounded like acceptance.
-
This is a perfect example of unconscious bias in action. He hadnâ€™t even realised what heâ€™d done, and he certainly hadnâ€™t meant to cause offence. Speaking up is difficult. What if it becomes confrontational? What if I get emotional when I try to explain how their words or actions affected me? Will it make any difference?  We have to push past these concerns and speak up anyway because it is the only way to make the unconscious, conscious.  So, if you find yourself in a position where you are being treated unfairly or unequally, try one of the three strategies I explain in this video. -
Iâ€™ve also put together a free PDF to help you to walk through the steps of speaking up. You can get it at www.debrasearle.com/bias . Iâ€™d recommend printing it and stashing it in a notebook or your top drawer at work, just in case!  The good news is that the thought of speaking up is always much worse than the reality and, in my experience running the Diversity & Inclusion consultancy MIX, most people are shocked to find that they may have inadvertently hurt you or caused offence and are open to being re-educated. -

Om mensen een duidelijk beeld te geven wat straatintimidatie is, kun je het nu zelf ervaren met onze VR experience in Amsterdam. Houd onze events in de gaten, zodat je de kans krijgt om de bril op te zetten, maar binnenkort ook online te zien.

Sunny-Girl runs an automotive business that specialises in panel repair and spray painting. Sheâ€™s been operating outside Windhoek, Namibia, since 2016. â€œSince I grew up, Iâ€™ve loved cars. It was so interesting. Even if my father came home, the first thing I would do is come and check if the car was fine. That is how I grew up, I really love to deal with cars,â€ she says.

The men she works with are happy to share their passion with her and work together as a team. Some of her male customers are surprised to see a woman with her own garage but are always impressed.

Our AWOME (Accelerating Women-Owned Micro-Enterprises) programme has helped her develop key management skills; how to keep the books, how to market the business, how to use WhatsApp and Facebook, and organise salaries. â€œI know that AWOME has polished me into a different shape. And then they made my business shiny,â€ Sunny-Girl says.

She already has six members of staff. In the future she aims to have a better workshop with more resources and tools, and to work with government and company cars.

Sunny-Girl is one of over 1,250 women micro-entrepreneurs who we are aiming to support through our AWOME programme. Weâ€™re working in partnership with @UNWomen and governments to accelerate women-owned micro-enterprises across Botswana, Namibia and South Africa.

hashtags:
Congratulations @debeersgroup, on 2 years working with @unwomen! #DiamondsDoGood 
#Repost @debeersgroup ******
Today weâ€™re celebrating the two-year anniversary of our partnership with UN Women. We hold our commitment to standing with women and girls close to our hearts because we believe that by supporting women, it creates a positive ripple effect that can help many more people. Through our HeForShe partnership with UN Women we have committed to creating a more equitable business and society for the wider communities connected to our business. Over the last two years, we have made great progress - here are some of the highlights to date!

We are committed to driving greater gender representation across our own business. We've almost doubled our appointment rate of women into senior leadership positions, run workshops to engage male employees on the topic of gender equality and provided lactation rooms in our mining operations to make life easier for mothers returning to work.

We are committed to supporting women and girls within our diamond producing communities. Through our AWOME (Accelerating Women-Owned Micro-â€‹Enterprises) programme we have supported over 700 women micro-entrepreneurs across South Africa and Namibia, and are now expanding the programme into Botswana. Weâ€™re also helping build the next generation of women leaders in STEM (science, technology, engineering and maths) subjects in Canada and southern Africa. Our investment is providing science camps and scholarships to help inspire and train young women.

We are committed to being a positive force for gender equality through our brand marketing. We have implemented inclusive marketing guidelines, which aim to avoid gender stereotypes and rather portray both men and women realistically and positively. 
Link in bio to find out more.
#standingwithwomen #buildingforever #inclusionweek #HeForShe @UNWomen

-IWB ROUNDTABLE DISCUSSION- 
Alhamdulillah. Everything went well. Penggulungan dan pembentangan hasil dan laporan kajian berkenaan dengan "Diskriminasi Gender Dalam Amalan Pekerjaan di Kalangan Penjawat Awam di Negeri Selangor", YB Puan DR. Siti Mariah memberikan maklumbalas yang memuaskan, berlapang dada menerima dan mendengar 'findings', dan akan menambah baik polisi dalam kerajaan negeri yang berkaitan dengan 'Gender Equality'. Thanks to Institut Wanita Berdaya (IWB) Selangor atas kesedaran dan mengambil berat tentang perkara ini, semoga hasrat selangor untuk menjadi negeri idaman tercapai dengan salah satu kelebihannya adalah dapat mengurangkan dan mengawal diskriminasi gender. 
Thanks to my research team (all the Doctors, Assoc. Prof) for the opportunity given to me, to join the team, to gain knowledges and experiences.

Iâ€™m back on the road with my hubby @rob.lea as he continues his ride across the USA! So far, heâ€™s biked over 2,500 miles/4,000 km in the last 28 days as the final leg of his Ultimate World Triathlon (his self-created challenge to climb Everest, swim the English Channel and ride across USA in six months).â£
â£
I think we all thought this bike ride was going to be the easy part, but we totally underestimated the physical and logistical challenges! Weâ€™ve been figuring it out as we go along. I am so jealous I canâ€™t ride the entire thing with him due to my knee (which is feeling really good), but Iâ€™m still riding with him every day and then riding back to the car to get 20-40 miles of my own in before I return to crewing duties. Iâ€™m hoping I can stay with him through the finish of his ride, which we estimate will be in less than two weeks! Keep checking his page and website for updates and cheering him on!!! â£
â£
And remember what heâ€™s doing it for: to raise awareness for menâ€™s role in advocating for gender equality. Iâ€™m so proud of him for using his goal to talk about a bigger issue. We know an athletic endeavor isnâ€™t going to change the world, but if we can get even one person to think about the role they play in making the world a better place, we feel like weâ€™ve won. â£

Dear Wisconsin,â£
â£
It was my first time visiting you. I didnâ€™t know exactly what to expect, but I was impressed. I crossed into you after crossing the mighty Mississippi River. The riding was interesting as I peddled through marshlands and wetlands to begin my journey across you.â£
ğŸš´ğŸ¼â€â™‚ï¸â£
Marshlands gave way to more rolling hills that I had not seen for a while. Although my legs are still tired, the variety in your terrain was welcome.  Rolling hills then gave way to more agriculture and lots of cornfields. But letâ€™s not forget the cows and the dairy. I enjoyed cheese curds ğŸ§€ all the way across your beautiful state :-). â£
ğŸš´ğŸ¼â€â™‚ï¸â£
Your capital, Madison and the University of Wisconsin are stunning. I really appreciated the commitment to cyclists in your city. And from Madison all the way to Milwaukee I was able to enjoy some of the most beautiful bike paths Iâ€™ve encounter. â£
ğŸš´ğŸ¼â€â™‚ï¸â£
Milwaukee was probably mostly what I would have imagined. Previously an industrial town that seems to have new legs and vibrancy. But it was also another mile stone to reach the Great Lakes and ride your shores south. â£
ğŸš´ğŸ¼â€â™‚ï¸â£
Probably most of all I will remember Wisconsin for the culture. You can tell Wisconians are proud of their states and their history.  I took extra notice of how well manicured your lawns and gardens were and how well-kept the houses were. Until next time, drink Wisconsibly my friends. ğŸ»â£
ğŸš´ğŸ¼â€â™‚ï¸â£

Title: Beat the Puss y Up.

Hyper aware of the derogatory language our culture accepts without blinking an eye, this piece is exploring gender bias and sexism in language. â€œBeat the Pussy Upâ€ is a commonly used phrase in rap lyrics and people are singing it without considering the repercussions of their words. To me, the phrase is literally referring to raping a woman, but according to www.urbandictionary.com, the verb means to f*** the pussy and is â€œcommonly used in street talk and hip-hop cultureâ€. This language perpetuates the idea that women are sex objects for men to conquest. The reproductive organs also loosely resemble a bull skull as a symbol of womenâ€™s strength and resilience. The painting is an anatomical view of a womanâ€™s genitals and I chose to accentuate the fabricâ€™s qualities by tearing and fraying the edges, which also serve as a comparison to â€œBeating the Pussy Upâ€. .
.

I want to always use my plaform to spread light. Sometimes that means having hard conversations like this one.

Since moving to AsunciÃ³n in March, I have completely had to go online with my business. All of my clients live in the states, and all of the networking I do is online. I love meeting and connecting with new faces! I've used Instagram for that and have made some really meaningful relationships through connecting on here.

Today I got a message from a man introducing himself and asking where I'm from. I honestly haven't gotten very many appropriate and work related messages from men in the history of me working online, I block and report innaproproate messages I get from men on a regular basis.

But this time... I thought... "Maybe this time it's different... Maybe I should give this man a chance. Maybe he is actually interested in the work that I'm doing, perhaps he is messaging me because he wants to set up a session." So. I responded with a short and professional message. He then proceeded to get my business email and started not only emailing me but also sending me innaproproate messages over Google Hangouts. Predictable, yet it broke my heart.

I am asking each woman who has ever recieved innaproproate messages from men to reply to this message with a â¤ï¸ or a âœŠ. For positive change to happen, first there has to be this awareness.

Let's stand together through this and show people that this common issue is not okay, we will continue standing up for what is right, and through bringing awareness in, make a positive change.ğŸ’ ~ Please pass this message on. Let's make a ripple. ~

â–«ï¸
Medical school classes are now gender-balanced. Women graduates need to be aware of the inherent barriers to advancement. Itâ€™s not just about pay... itâ€™s that promotion or leadership position that we didnâ€™t even know was available. Itâ€™s the lack of fierce women mentors to create a pipeline. Itâ€™s the subtle and not-so-subtle gender biases and harassment that knock us down. .

â£
The thirty women surfers profiled in this thrilling collection can rip a wave with the best of them. Hailing from all over the world, each surfer is featured in spectacular photography and with their own inspirational words. Thereâ€˜s American professional surfer Lindsay Steinriede on how her fatherâ€˜s death has inspired her career; French board shaper Valerie Duprat on how she got her start â€œsculpting foamâ€œ; Conchita RoÌˆssler, founder of Mooana Retreat in Portugal, on connecting mind, body and spirit; and Australian photographer Cait Miers on empowering women. Youâ€˜ll also meet surfers who are over sixty, who surf while pregnant, who captain boats, teach yoga and make movies. Breathtaking photography captures these women from every angle, on and off the waves, in some of the worldâ€˜s most visually stunning locations.â£â£

ğŸ’µ GENDER PAY GAP ğŸ’µ â£â£
â£â£
Nobody likes talking about moneyâ€¦especially doctors. â£â£
â£â£
â—ï¸But the gender pay gap NEEDS to be addressed. â—ï¸â£â£
â£â£
I am lucky to be part of a private practice anesthesiology group that pays everyone equally.Â Â Not everyone is so fortunate. â£â£
â£â£
@medscape recently came out with their annual compensation report and the gender pay gaps STILL exists. Yes, even in 2019!! â£ğŸ™„â£
â£â£
In anesthesiology, men were paid $63,000 more than women. In other specialties, the gap is even higher. ğŸ“ˆâ£â£
â£â£
ğŸšº Itâ€™s not because women work part time. Part-time physician salaries were not included in the analysis. â£â£
â£â£
ğŸšº Itâ€™s not because women were in lower-paying specialties. Within higher paying specialities, there was still a pay gap. â£â£
â£â£
ğŸšº Itâ€™s not because of the practice model. This analysis only looked at the employed model and there was still a pay gap. â£â£
â£â£
ğŸšº Itâ€™s not because of age. Physicians were compared against their own age group and there was still a pay gap. â£â£
â£â£
âŒIt really could be due discrimination, and that is a sad reality in 2019. âŒâ£â£
â£â£
With women now being the majority enrolling in medical schools (50.7%Â ğŸšº ), this pay gap needs to be addressed and rectified. â£â£
â£â£
Women have the same level of training and experience as their male physician colleagues. We take out the same massive student loans. Studies have shown time and again that patients do better overall when women physicians are in charge of their medical care. â£â£
â£
âœ¨We are privileged to be physicians and itâ€™s an honor to care for our patients. âœ¨â£
â£
âŒBut donâ€™t take advantage of our altruism.âŒâ£
â£
Itâ€™s time for women to get compensated fairly for our work. â£ğŸ‘©ğŸ»â€âš•ï¸â£
â£â£
Thank you @natasha.mom.md for inviting me to this important campaign, #paywomenequallyâ£â£

hashtags: don't look after other persons and think "i wanna be like them" just because you think they're prettier, have a better body, a nicer voice or a sweeter laugh. there's one reason you're not like them: everyone's unique! and unique doesn't mean different from all the others or worse than them, no. it means that no one in this whole world can be compared to you. you are the only one who looks like you do, speaks like you do and laughs like you do. even identical twins are not fully identical, there are still some little differences between them, differences that make each one of them special. you have something that no one else in this world has: the combination of your hair, eyes, face, body, voice and character. you are the person who can change the world and who makes others around you smile. don't you think that's amazing? you're incredibly beautiful, your laugh causes others people's happiness and your voice is so cute! love yourself and be proud of it.

.

Mi riferisco soprattutto a quegli uomini che quando si ritrovano a fare commenti del genere intendono sminuire la persona che hanno di fronte. Una donna non deve essere per forza vestita seguendo determinati standard per fare un colloquio di lavoro, se provassimo un po' di piÃ¹ ad andare oltre a tutto il contorno di una persona, di certo non si verificherebbero situazioni del genere o per lo meno sarebbero meno frequenti. PerchÃ© sÃ¬, ancora sono frequenti, per questo Ã¨ cosÃ¬ importante parlarne. |ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§ We are sharing today a post by Maria Prisco, her reflection about a job interview, "proper" clothes and stereotypes!Â 
Let's be proud of ourselves no matter what we wear! 
Is it so hard to understand that we can be both? Beautiful and intelligent? Above all, I am talking about those men, who make comments like this to belittle the person they face. A woman shouldn't have to dress within certain "standards" for a job interview, if we try a little more to go beyond the whole exterior of a person, certainly such situations would not occur or at least would be less frequent.
Because yes, they are still frequent, so it is so important to talk about it.
In our work with Beyondwhattheysell we will soon address the delicate issue of sexism and harassment at the workplace. Keep following us if you want to know more!

â£â£â£â£â£â£

These past few weeks have been like something out of the dystopian teen fiction novels I used to binge read back in the day. A world where even a post office isn't safe. Yessess man. We were angry. We were loud. So f*cking loud. And the silence we got back was deafening. 
Beyond a government that actually works it feels like our hands are tied. Somehow the culture of rape and harassment has been made a "you problem, not a me problem" kind of situation. And that sucks. It feels like we're not valued from the top of government to the bottoms of that fckbois old skool Vans. 
And it made me exhausted. So angry, so many clear indications of what's BEEN happening. Yet people are still  demanding "prove it". Yet in our workplaces people wear green and gold on Bok Friday, but didn't wearing black the one time we asked for solidarity. I had to take a step back because I felt worn out. Heavy with the realisation that so many people in my life we're not who I thought they were. 
And then I remembered. Natural hair brought with it an amazing support network. Every day I log into a community who support each other. Who want to see their people win. Who will give you advice from conditioner to career moves. So now I move forward with that intent. To be the change I need to see in this world, or at least in my circles. The support is extending from hair. To value ourselves so much that they cannot ignore how actually valuable each female actually is. If you're already part of this online family, thank you for teaching me how to boss babe every damn day. If you're not, consider this your formal invite. Let's take over the world now? ğŸ’œ

.
â€œWhen at 15, my girlfriends started dropping out of their beloved sports teams, because they didnâ€™t want to appear muscle-y, when at 18 my male friends were unable to express their feelings, I decided that I was a feminist.â€
.

Team Decoding Patriarchal Codes organised an event for the students of Dayal Singh College in collaboration with their Women's Development Cell @virangana.dsc on 21.09.10.
 Artist Gopal Namjoshi @gopalnamjoshistudio was joined by Gender and Sexuality Rights Activist Arpit Bhalla @thequartproject in an interactive session that encouraged the audience to analyse and express their own experiences with Patriarchy. This was followed by a Creative Session in which the audience stripped off the patriarch's mask in their posters and designs.

Performance artist Hiten Noonwaal @hiten.noonwal was the show stopper so to say, topping the event off with his marvelous dance performance that moved to the beat of coexistence- a theme that consistently runs through Gopal Namjoshi's work.

A few still moments from yesterday's event.

Follow @decodingpatriarchalcodes for more!

Consent is sexy.â  ğŸ‘‰ğŸ½ What Consent Involves:â 
â 
Consent means the agreement given to a sexual partner at the moment the partners take part in sexual activities.â 
â 
This consent must be voluntary. This means that it must be given freely and not forced. Consent must also be informed.  Informed means that the person consenting understands the consequences of the decision. If the choice is not free and informed, then the person's consent is not valid.â 
â 
There is no consent if someone refuses to participate in a sexual activity but is forced into it anyway.â 
â 
Also, the consent must be clear, and it must be given personally by the person taking part in the sexual activity. Consent based on the words or actions of someone else is not valid.â 
â 
ğŸ‘‰ğŸ½ How Consent Must Be Givenâ 
â 
The law doesn't say exactly how consent to sexual activities must be given. It is enough that someone consents through words, through actions or both these ways. Therefore, consent doesn't have to be verbal or in writing.â 
â 
#KnowYourRightsâ 
Now go enjoy some hot ğŸ‘‰ğŸ½consensual sex!â

When she becomes a mother

A moment of celebration at home,
While a moment of concern for her career.

Sheâ€™s a window to the universeâ€™s next generation,
While her window to opportunities almost collapses.

Her dictionary is being redefined,
Not be her but her insignificant others. 
From work challenges and successes 
She progresses and yet regresses, 
To sacrifices and compromises

What a hypocritical world we stay in ?

Thereâ€™s a almost compulsion for a woman 
To be a mother,
While she ainâ€™t celebrated in the workforce.

Fathers need empowerment for their daughters, 
But choose to disempower the expectant mothers (daughters of others), when they play bosses

What a hypocritical world we stay! 
Also when these Bosses are themselves mothers, and have mothers working under them, 
Are they truly empathetic managers ? 
How will we make this world a better place ever? 
If work-designations-corporations-investors donâ€™t see families progressing and donâ€™t celebrate their employees. 
How will we make this world a better place? - 
Roshni Khanna,

Believe survivors. 
When I was nine I was molested by a older male neighbor. Two male police officers came to my house. They sat on either side of me on my couch. I remember putting my feet up against the edge of the coffee table to hide them shaking as much as I could. They were nice to me. But it was traumatic. They told my mom to take me to the hospital. My mom had been a victim of repeated incest rape as a child and teen. I asked why they wanted me to go to the hopsital. She screamed at me "To see if he put his penis inside you, DEAR." She was struggling with her own demons this brought up for her. I didn't talk about it anymore. Many other girls on the street had been molested. I told the cops all. They interviewed each girl who were mad at me for telling. Nothing whatsoever happened to him. He grabbed our budding breats and pinched them and literally grabbed our pussys. Nothing happened. My dad stayed friends with him. I told my dad to go fuck himself when I was a bit older, (there were a lot of other issues there besides this). It was satisfying. 
I have other stories. This is the one I will share, today.

hashtags: Humbled and honoured to be the featured volunteer of @unwomenuk. We need to raise more awareness on gender inequality and how poetry and poetry spaces can be exclusive or unsafe for women and gender minorities. Many spaces within the London poetry scene, including @thepoetrysociety where we hold our events, need to adopt clear and accountable policies and guidelines to be safer for and more inclusive of women and gender minorities, and take a stance against rape culture, against the desensitisation of gendered and sexual violence. It is undeniable that voices of LGBT+, BAME, and female poets have been systemically removed from the canon and some organisations still continue to do that. And we're really proud to have made a small change, albeit small, by creating a diverse night with so many powerful voices - a few of which were heard for the first time - in order to raise awareness on gender equality. We are so proud of every single one of our poets (tagged in the photo) ğŸ‘ğŸ‘ğŸ™ğŸŒ¹ #poetsversus #feminism #genderequality #heforshe #drawaline #poetsvsgenderinequality #endgenderbasedviolence #genderequality #equalityforall #blacklivesmatter #translivesmatter #nonbinarylivesmatter #womensrights #reproductiverights #fightracism #fightsexism #londonpoetry #londonpoets

My students participated in a Socratic seminar yesterday that I canâ€™t get out of my head. It began as a conversation of discrimination against women, but it became a discussion of stereotypes that are harmful for both women and men. 
Particularly the idea that all athletes (male) are macho, sexist, perverts was particularly offensive. Yâ€™all... I have to admit that I believed the stereotype to a point. I was ashamed of myself as I like to think of myself as aware and open, but on that point I had never done the work to correct the ideas that no longer serve me and my students. 
I admit this to encourage you to do the work - confront the stereotypes of high school or gender based stereotypes or culture based. Redefine them and work from that point. 
Itâ€™s worth the conversation. 
#iteach #iteachhighschoolenglish #quitstereotyping 
Also thank you @emmawatson for your #heforshe speech!

Decoding Patriarchal Codes is all about taking an initiative to open up a conversation on the impacts of Patriarchy on the society and we aim to do achieve the same by having a series of events alongside the Public Art Installation in October.  We are thrilled to announce the first event of the pre Installation phase of the project.
We are collaborating with the students of @virangana.dsc to organise an interactive discussion with the Artist Gopal Namjoshi (@gopalnamjoshistudio ) and Arpit Bhalla (@ye_mausam_bheega_bheega ), Gender Rights Activist and founder of @thequartproject 
The talk will be followed by a creative session that will encourage the audience to express their narratives in a format they are comfortable with.
Join us for the event and share your views on the theme!
Follow @decodingpatriarchalcodes for more.

hashtags: Five years ago today, a young Emma Watson stood up in front of the UN and gave a galvanising speech imploring men to join the battle for gender equality. The #HeForShe movement has since grown to become a wider clarion call asking ALL of us to commit to gender equality. To mark the five year anniversary, UN Women is inviting all of us to take the pledge over the next month and prove that change is possible by standing together. Tap link in bio to join the movement today and share with others to spread the word. Go on. You know you want to.âœŠ #equality #equalityforall #HeForShe5 #IamHeForShe

Dear Mione.
I just wanted to congratulate youğŸ’•
I hope you're all good and celebrate wellâœ¨
You're such a strong, strong person. You not only taught us that brightness is always very useful in life but furthermore that friendship and bravery are equally as important, if not more.
In my opinion your brilliance and cleverness shows the most in the way you duel. You know so many unused spells (Glisseo is just iconic) and use them to distract your contra in the right moment; not shooting around the "hard ones" but seeing the perfect moment to surprise the enemy and grab them by their stupidity.
I also wanted to point out what a wonderful companion and friend you are; always supportive and giving everything to protect your loved once. True power and bravery.
Furthermore, your charactical change through time was just impressive; from a bit annoying and know-it-all to a true fighter with amazing qualities.
You showed us that we all can change for good if we want to and that we are allowed to use our talents, and may they only be knowing lots of maybe unnecessary things. In the right moment they'll be useful. 
I really admire you and look up to you as a role model.
Your characteristic qualities are the ones one should try to achieve, at least I'm trying every day to be a bit like you.
Well, celebrate well, legendğŸ’•
I love you so much and will always support you.
Greetings, lots of love and yours forever,
Toniâ¤ï¸âœ¨

hashtags:
- Meet The Artists -
Ariel Baillieâ™€ï¸
Creative Artist

I have been drawing since I was able to pick up a crayon. I have always loved arts and crafts and creating anything that came to mind. Growing up as a very nomadic child I was exposed to different parts of the world at a very young age which opened up my mind to a whole new perspective.

I didnt start focusing on acrylic paintings until I moved to vancouver in 2018. The response I received from my pieces opened up opportunities I never thought could become a reality. It sparked something within me and I have never looked back.

As each piece I created recieved such different interpretations it hit me to want to portray a message that could mean more to someone than just "I like that". This is where I met the beautiful mind of Aubree.
I had done a couple sketches of females that I posted on an Instagram story and she asked me if she could use them. This being my first time that anyone has asked to collaborate on a piece I was Instantly intrigued.
The piece she created blew me out of the water and I never thought I could see my sketches come to life the way she merged them together and put colour into it. I feel like this piece is where it all started for TPIF to come to light.
To empower each other to create and be represented in the art world never has meant so much to me then this moment right now. To see creative minds of women come together and make an impact is exactly what we want to do with TPIF.
The time is now to go for our dreams and create a reality with our goals.
â€œWomen donâ€™t need to find a voice, they have a voice, and they need to feel empowered to use it, and people need to be encouraged to listen.â€ â€“ Meghan Markle

TPIF is created to empower women to use their gifts of creativity and show the arts community that they deserve the spotlight. Once we allow women to understand and exercise their power, they can remake the world.
